- 50g rolled oats, plus extra for sprinkling
- 1½ tsp baking powder
- 1½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
- 1½ tsp cinnamon
- 100g blueberry
- 2 tbsp mixed seed, we used pumpkin, sunflower and flaxseed

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat the oven to 180°C / 160°C fan / gas 4. Line a 12-hole muffin tray with 12 large muffin cases.
2. In a jug, mix the eggs, yogurt, oil, apple sauce, mashed banana, honey and vanilla.
3. Tip the remaining ingredients (except the seeds) into a large bowl, add a pinch of salt and mix to combine.
4. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry, then mix briefly until you have a smooth batter — don’t overmix as this will make the muffins heavy.
5. Spoon the batter between the cases. Sprinkle the muffins with the extra oats and the mixed seeds.
6. Bake for 25–30 minutes until golden and well risen, and a skewer inserted into the centre of a muffin comes out clean.
7. Remove from the oven, transfer to a wire rack and leave to cool. Store in a sealed container for up to 3 days.
explanation: The answer discusses muffins, includes a 45-minute total time and similar ingredients, but it provides a banana muffin recipe instead of the requested blueberry wholemeal muffins. It partially addresses the timing and muffin concept but not the exact blueberry version.

question: How do I make a multi-layer malted cake with cream-cheese buttercream (large amounts of butter and icing sugar) and a ganache drip for a celebration?
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Chocolate drip cake
Difficulty: A challenge
Total cooking time: 180 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- For the malt sponges (enough for 2 x 20 cm tins)
  - 200 g unsalted butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
  - 250 g golden caster sugar
  - 3 large eggs
  - 225 g plain flour
  - 25 g powdered malt drink
  - 2 tsp baking powder
  - 100 g natural yogurt
  - 2 tsp vanilla extract

- For the chocolate sponges (enough for 2 x 20 cm tins)
  - 175 g unsalted butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
  - 250 g golden caster sugar
  - 3 large eggs
  - 225 g plain flour
  - 25 g cocoa powder
  - 2 tsp baking powder
  - 50 g natural yogurt
  - 100 g dark chocolate, melted and cooled a little
  - 100 ml boiling water

- For the honeycomb
  - Butter or flavourless oil, for greasing
  - 200 g golden caster sugar
  - 5 tbsp golden syrup
  - 2 tsp bicarbonate of soda

- For the cream-cheese buttercream (large amount of butter & icing sugar)
  - 250 g pack slightly salted butter, softened
  - 750 g icing sugar
  - 3 tbsp powdered malt drink
  - 1 tsp vanilla extract
  - 280 g tub full-fat cream cheese

- For the ganache drip
  - 100 g dark chocolate, finely chopped
  - 75 ml double cream

- For decoration
  - 37 g pack Maltesers
  - Honeycomb shards (from above)

Step-by-step instructions

1. Preheat and prepare tins
   - Heat the oven to 180°C / 160°C fan / gas 4.
   - Grease and line the bases of 2 x 20 cm cake tins with baking parchment.

2. Make the malt sponges
   - Put the 200 g butter and 250 g caster sugar in a large bowl and whisk until pale and fluffy.
   - Add the eggs one at a time, whisking well between each addition.
   - Tip in the 225 g plain flour, 25 g powdered malt drink and 2 tsp baking powder (with 1/4 tsp salt if you like), fold together.
   - Add the 100 g natural yogurt and 2 tsp vanilla extract, give everything a final stir.
   - Divide the mixture between the 2 prepared tins, level the tops and bake on the middle shelf for 25–30 minutes or until a skewer pushed into the centre comes out clean.
   - Cool for 10 minutes in the tins, then remove, peel off the baking parchment and transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

3. Make the chocolate sponges
   - Grease and line the tins as before.
   - In the same bowl (no need to wash), cream the 175 g butter and 250 g sugar until pale and fluffy, then add the eggs one at a time, mixing until combined.
   - Sift in the 225 g plain flour, 25 g cocoa powder and 2 tsp baking powder (with 1/4 tsp salt if you like). Fold to combine.
   - Add the 50 g natural yogurt, the melted 100 g dark chocolate and 100 ml boiling water. Stir until combined.
   - Divide between the tins and bake for 25–30 minutes, testing with a skewer as before.
   - Cool in the tins for 10 minutes, turn out, remove the parchment and cool completely.
   - Note: The sponges can be made up to 2 days ahead; wrap cooled sponges tightly in cling film.

4. Make the honeycomb
   - Grease a baking tray with a little butter or oil.
   - Put 200 g sugar and 5 tbsp golden syrup in a large pan. Warm over a medium heat and leave to bubble to a liquid caramel — do not stir.
   - When the caramel colour is to your liking, add the 2 tsp bicarbonate of soda and quickly stir into the syrup.
   - Before the bubbles die down, pour the foaming mixture onto the prepared tray and set aside for about 30 minutes to cool and firm up.
   - When cooled, break into tall shards for decoration.

5. Make the cream-cheese buttercream
   - In your largest mixing bowl, beat the 250 g softened butter with half of the 750 g icing sugar, the 3 tbsp powdered malt drink and 1 tsp vanilla until smooth.
   - Add the remaining icing sugar and the 280 g cream cheese, and beat again until well combined. (Take care not to overmix or the icing may become runny.)

6. Assemble the cake (stacking and crumb coat)
   - Put one sponge on a cake stand or board, sticking it down with a small blob of icing.
   - Use about 1/4 of the icing to stack the cakes, alternating between the malt and chocolate sponges (e.g., malt, chocolate, malt, chocolate — depending on how many layers you have).
   - Place the final sponge on top, flat-side up.
   - Use a palette knife to cover the entire cake with a thin layer of the icing, filling gaps between sponges — this is the crumb coat.
   - Chill the cake in the fridge for 30 minutes to firm up the crumb coat.

7. Finish icing
   - Once chilled, use the remaining icing to completely cover the cake. Pile icing on top, then ease it over the edge and down the sides with a palette knife; smooth or texture as you prefer.
   - Chill the iced cake for another 30 minutes.

8. Make the ganache drip
   - Put the 100 g finely chopped dark chocolate in a bowl.
   - Heat the 75 ml double cream in a small pan until just steaming. Pour the hot cream over the chocolate and leave to melt for 5–10 minutes.
   - Stir to make a glossy ganache, then set aside to firm up slightly — you want it pourable but not too runny for drip control.

9. Apply the drip and decorate
   - When the ganache is the correct consistency, remove the cake from the fridge.
   - Spoon the ganache over the top edge of the cake, encouraging it to drip down the sides with your spoon (start at the back to practice).
   - Fill in the middle of the top of the cake with ganache as well.
   - Break the honeycomb into shards and stack them on top of the cake.
   - Finish with whole and halved Maltesers, adding a few around the base and some honeycomb crumbs.

10. Serve and store
   - The cake is best served within 2–3 hours of assembling but will still be tasty for up to 3 days.
   - Store leftovers in the fridge and allow to come back to room temperature before serving.

Enjoy your celebration cake!
explanation: Provides a complete recipe for a multi-layer malted cake with cream-cheese buttercream and a ganache drip, matching the user's request.

question: Quick pitta bread pizzas using plum tomatoes and shallot — simple supper idea
llm_answer:
Recipe: Quick pitta pizzas

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 20 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not specified

Ingredients
- 4 wholewheat pitta breads
- 4 tsp sun-dried tomato purée
- 3 ripe plum tomatoes, diced
- 1 shallot, thinly sliced
- 85 g chorizo, diced
- 50 g mature cheddar, grated
- A few basil leaves (optional)
- Green salad to serve (optional)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat your oven to 200°C (180°C fan) / Gas 6. Put a baking sheet inside the oven to heat up.
2. While the oven and sheet heat, split each pitta if you prefer and lay them out on a board or tray.
3. Spread each pitta with 1 teaspoon of sun-dried tomato purée.
4. Top each pitta with the diced plum tomatoes, thinly sliced shallot, diced chorizo and a sprinkle of grated mature cheddar.
5. Carefully place the prepared pittas onto the hot baking sheet in the oven.
6. Bake for about 10 minutes, until the pittas are crisp, the cheese has melted and the chorizo has slightly browned at the edges.
7. Remove from the oven, scatter over basil leaves if using, and serve immediately with a green salad if you like.
explanation: The answer provides a quick pitta pizza recipe that uses plum tomatoes and shallot and fits the 'quick, simple supper' concept.

question: Easy vegan chocolate cake recipe made with oat milk and dairy-free spread — can I make this in about 55 minutes?
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Vegan chocolate cake

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 55 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients:
- 150g dairy-free spread, plus extra for the tins
- 300ml dairy-free milk (we used oat milk)
- 1 tbsp cider vinegar
- 300g self-raising flour
- 200g golden caster sugar
- 4 tbsp cocoa powder
- 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
- ½ tsp vanilla extract
- 100g dairy-free dark chocolate
- 200g dairy-free spread (for the buttercream)
- 400g icing sugar
- 5 tbsp cocoa powder (for the buttercream)
- 1 tbsp dairy-free milk, such as oat milk (for the buttercream)
- Handful of fresh, seasonal fruits such as cherries, blackberries or figs (to decorate)

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Heat the oven to 190°C (170°C fan) / gas mark 5. Grease the base and sides of 2 x 20cm sandwich tins with a little dairy-free spread, then line the bases with baking parchment.

2. Make the vegan "buttermilk": put the 300ml dairy-free milk (oat milk) in a jug and add the 1 tbsp cider vinegar. It will split — that’s normal. Set aside for a minute.

3. In a large bowl, put the 300g self-raising flour, 200g golden caster sugar, 4 tbsp cocoa powder, 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda and ½ tsp vanilla extract. Pour the milk-and-vinegar mixture into the dry ingredients and beat well until the batter is smooth.

4. Divide the mixture evenly between the two prepared tins and bake in the preheated oven for 25–30 minutes, or until a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean.

5. When baked, leave the sponges to cool in the tins for 10 minutes, then turn out onto wire racks to cool completely.

6. While the cakes cool, make the chocolate buttercream: break the 100g dairy-free dark chocolate into a heatproof bowl and melt in the microwave, stirring every 30 seconds until melted. Leave the melted chocolate to cool for about 5 minutes.

7. In another bowl, beat together 200g dairy-free spread and 400g icing sugar with a wooden spoon until combined. Sift in 5 tbsp cocoa powder and add a pinch of salt; mix well.

8. Pour the cooled melted chocolate and 1 tbsp dairy-free milk into the buttercream mixture and continue mixing until smooth and spreadable. (Adjust a little extra dairy-free milk if needed to reach desired consistency.)

9. Assemble the cake: sandwich the two cooled sponges together with about half of the buttercream, then pile the remaining buttercream on top and spread down the sides.

10. Decorate the finished cake with a handful of fresh, seasonal fruits such as cherries, blackberries or figs.

Notes:
- Total time (including baking and short cooling time) is about 55 minutes.
- Ensure sponges are fully cool before applying the buttercream to avoid it melting.
explanation: The answer directly confirms a total time of about 55 minutes for the requested vegan chocolate cake recipe (with oat milk and dairy-free spread) and provides the full recipe.

question: Healthy shepherd's pie around 438 kcal that counts as 3 of your five-a-day — what is this recipe?
llm_answer:
Slow cooker shepherd's pie
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 360 minutes
Calories: 438 kcal

Ingredients
- 1 tbsp olive oil
- 1 onion, finely chopped
- 3–4 thyme sprigs
- 2 carrots, finely diced
- 250 g lean (10%) mince lamb or beef
- 1 tbsp plain flour
- 1 tbsp tomato purée
- 400 g can lentils, or white beans
- 1 tsp Worcestershire sauce
- 650 g potatoes, peeled and cut into chunks
- 250 g sweet potatoes, peeled and cut into chunks
- 2 tbsp half-fat crème fraîche
- Pepper, to season
- Splash of water (optional)

Step-by-step instructions
1. If your slow cooker needs preheating, heat it now. Heat 1 tbsp olive oil in a large frying pan over medium heat.
2. Add the finely chopped onion and the thyme sprigs to the pan and fry for 2–3 minutes until the onion softens.
3. Add the diced carrots and continue to fry, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables start to brown.
4. Add the mince and fry for 1–2 minutes until it is no longer pink.
5. Stir in 1 tbsp plain flour and cook for another 1–2 minutes to combine.
6. Add 1 tbsp tomato purée and the drained 400 g can of lentils (or white beans). Season with black pepper and stir in 1 tsp Worcestershire sauce. If the mixture seems too dry, add a splash of water.
7. Scrape the meat-and-lentil mixture into the slow cooker and spread evenly.
8. Meanwhile, put the potatoes and sweet potatoes into two separate pans of simmering water and cook for 12–13 minutes, or until tender.
9. Drain the cooked potatoes and sweet potatoes well, then mash together with 2 tbsp half-fat crème fraîche until smooth. Season to taste with pepper.
10. Spoon the mash over the mince and lentil mixture in the slow cooker to cover.
11. Cook on Low for 5 hours (the mixture should be bubbling at the sides when ready).
12. Optional: if you like a crisp topping, transfer the pie topping under a hot grill for a few minutes to brown before serving.

Enjoy your healthy shepherd’s pie (approx. 438 kcal).
explanation: The answer provides a complete slow cooker shepherd's pie recipe with approximately 438 kcal, including ingredients and step-by-step instructions, aligning with the request for a 438 kcal version that could count as three of your five-a-day.

question: Can I make this easy shortbread (uses 140g rice flour and 300g plain flour) gluten-free by adjusting the flours?
llm_answer:
Shortbread recipe
Difficulty: Easy

Ingredients:
- 300g butter, softened
- 140g golden caster sugar, plus 4 tbsp extra for sprinkling
- 300g plain flour
- 140g rice flour
- Pinch of salt

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Place the butter and 140g of the golden caster sugar in a food processor and whizz until smooth.
2. Tip in both flours and a pinch of salt, then whizz until the mixture comes together.
3. Using your hands, roughly spread the mixture out in a 20 x 30 x 4 cm baking tray. Cover with cling film and smooth over until there are no wrinkles.
4. Place the tin in the fridge, uncooked, for at least 30 minutes and up to 2 days.
5. Heat the oven to 180°C / 160°C fan / gas 4.
6. Remove the cling film, then lightly mark the shortbread all over with a fork.
7. Sprinkle with the remaining 4 tbsp of sugar, then bake for 20–25 minutes.
8. Leave to cool in the tin, then cut into 24 thin slices.

Total cooking time: 40 minutes
Calories: 188 kcal per serving
explanation: The answer provides a full shortbread recipe but does not address whether or how to make it gluten-free or adjust flours to remove gluten.

question: Quick dessert: what are the ingredients and total time for the 5-star rated mocha pots?
llm_answer:
Recipe: 5-minute mocha pots
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 7 minutes
Calories (kcal): not specified

Ingredients:
- 200g milk or dark chocolate with coffee, broken into chunks
- 300ml pot double cream
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- 2 tbsp crème fraîche

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Melt the chocolate: microwave the chocolate for 2 minutes, stirring halfway through, or melt it over a pan of gently simmering water. Leave it to cool a little.
2. Whip the cream: in a bowl, use an electric whisk to whip the double cream with the vanilla extract until lightly whipped.
3. Combine: fold the cooled, melted chocolate into the whipped cream until fully combined and smooth.
4. Serve: split the mixture between four small bowls or ramekins. Top each with a dollop of crème fraîche.

question: 5-star rated, 4-ingredient piri-piri chicken pittas — what makes this easy recipe so popular?
llm_answer:
Piri‑piri chicken pittas
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 12 minutes
Calories: 471 kcal

Ingredients
- 4 chicken breasts
- 3 tbsp medium spice piri‑piri sauce
- 300g tub coleslaw
- 4 pitta breads

Step‑by‑step instructions
1. Prepare the chicken: cut each chicken breast into roughly 2 cm cubes.
2. Toss the chicken pieces in the 3 tbsp of piri‑piri sauce until evenly coated. Leave to marinate for a few minutes if you have time.
3. Preheat the grill to high.
4. Thread the coated chicken cubes onto four skewers, distributing the pieces evenly.
5. Grill the skewers on all sides for 10–12 minutes in total, turning so the chicken cooks through and gets a little charred at the edges. Ensure the chicken is cooked through (no pink inside and juices run clear).
6. While the chicken is grilling, warm the pittas in a toaster or under the grill for a minute or two until soft and heated.
7. Remove the chicken from the skewers and slice each pitta open. Stuff each pitta half with a portion of the coleslaw, then add the grilled piri‑piri chicken.
8. Serve immediately.
explanation: The answer provides a complete recipe and highlights its ease (4 ingredients, 12-minute cook time), which touches on factors that could drive popularity. However, it does not explicitly analyze or explain why the recipe is popular.

question: Simple no-bake marshmallow pops for kids — how easy is this recipe and how many servings from one pack of marshmallows?
llm_answer:
Marshmallows dipped in chocolate

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 15 minutes

Calories: 45 kcal (per marshmallow)

Ingredients:
- 50g white chocolate
- 50g milk chocolate
- Selection of cake sprinkles
- 1 bag marshmallows (about 200g)
- 1 pack lollipop sticks

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Heat the chocolates in separate bowls over simmering water (double boiler) or on a low setting in the microwave. Allow the melted chocolate to cool a little so it’s still dip-able but not too hot.
2. Put your chosen sprinkles on separate plates.
3. Push a cake pop or lolly stick into a marshmallow about halfway in.
4. Dip the marshmallow into the white or milk chocolate, allowing excess to drip off.
5. Immediately dip the chocolate-coated marshmallow into the sprinkles of your choice to decorate.
6. Place the finished marshmallow pops upright in a tall glass to set. Repeat with each marshmallow until finished.

question: Easy cheese & onion bread recipe using malted grain brown or wholemeal flour — ready in about 50 minutes?
llm_answer:
Recipe: Cheese & onion bread
Difficulty: Easy
Total time: 50 minutes
Calories: 183 kcal

Ingredients
- 400g malted grain brown bread flour, or wholemeal or granary bread flour
- 100g strong white bread flour
- 7g sachet easy-bake dried yeast (or 2 tsp quick dried yeast)
- 1½ tsp salt
- 1 tbsp soft butter
- 1 large onion, cut into thin wedges
- 1 tbsp olive oil
- 1 beaten egg
- 50g grated mature cheddar

Step-by-step instructions
1. Mix flours, yeast and salt
   - In a large mixing bowl, mix the malted brown (or wholemeal/granary) flour with the strong white flour, the dried yeast and the salt.
   - Add the soft butter and rub it into the flour with your fingertips.

2. Add water and form dough
   - Make a dip in the centre of the flour and pour in almost 300ml hand-warm (cool rather than hot) water.
   - Using a round-bladed knife, mix in enough of the remaining water (and a little more if needed) until the mixture comes together as a soft, not too sticky, dough.
   - Gather it into a ball with your hands.

3. Knead and first rise
   - Put the dough onto a very lightly floured surface and knead for 8–10 minutes until smooth and elastic, adding only the minimum extra flour if necessary.
   - Place the dough ball on the work surface, cover with an upturned clean large glass bowl, and leave for 45 minutes to 1 hour, or until doubled in size and light and springy (timing depends on room warmth).

4. Knock back and rest
   - Knock back the dough by lightly kneading just 3–4 times to remove large air bubbles. Shape into a ball.
   - Cover with the glass bowl and leave for 15 minutes.

5. Cook the onion
   - Fry the onion wedges in the olive oil until very lightly caramelised, then leave to cool.

6. Divide and shape
   - Cut the dough in half and shape each piece into a ball.
   - Cover with the glass bowl and leave for 15 minutes.
   - Flatten each ball into an 18cm round and place each on a large baking tray lined with baking parchment.
   - Make 6 deepish cuts in each round to mark them into 6 wedges.
   - Cover with a clean tea towel and leave for 40–45 minutes, or until doubled in size.

7. Finish and top
   - Preheat the oven as below while the dough is proving.
   - Brush the risen rounds with the beaten egg.
   - Scatter the cooled caramelised onion over the tops, then sprinkle with the grated mature cheddar.

8. Bake with steam for a crisp crust
   - Put a roasting tin in the bottom of the oven 20 minutes before baking and heat the oven to 230°C / 210°C fan / gas 8.
   - When ready to bake, put the risen bread in the oven and carefully pour about 250ml cold water into the hot roasting tin (this will hiss and create steam). Immediately lower the oven temperature to 220°C / 200°C fan / gas 7.
   - Bake for 30–35 minutes or until golden. If the onion is getting too brown, lay a piece of parchment over the top.

9. Cool and check
   - Remove from the oven and cool on a wire rack.
   - To check it’s done, tap the underside of the loaf — it should be firm and sound hollow.

Enjoy warm or cooled as desired.
explanation: The answer provides a complete cheese & onion bread recipe using malted brown/wholemeal flour and notes a total time around 50 minutes, directly addressing the user’s request.

question: Vanilla shortbread made with 2 egg yolks and good-quality vanilla extract — quick, low-effort biscuit (5-star rating)?
llm_answer:
Vanilla shortbread dough
Difficulty: Easy

Ingredients:
- 325g plain flour
- 200g chilled salted butter
- 125g golden caster sugar
- 2 tsp good-quality vanilla extract
- 2 large free-range egg yolks

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Tip the flour into a food processor.
2. Cut the chilled butter into small pieces and drop them into the bowl, then whizz until the mixture looks like breadcrumbs.
3. Add the sugar, vanilla and egg yolks and whizz to a small dough.
4. Tip the dough onto a sheet of non-stick baking parchment and use the paper to roll the dough into a log shape, twisting the ends like a cracker. Chill for 3 hours or overnight.
5. Heat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan). Slice the log into 1 cm-thick rounds and arrange on a baking sheet, leaving gaps between them.
6. Bake for 15–20 minutes until golden. Leave to firm on the baking sheet for 3–4 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool.

Total cooking time: 15 minutes
Calories (kcal): 0.0
explanation: The answer provides a vanilla shortbread recipe using 2 egg yolks and good-quality vanilla extract, labeled easy with ingredients and step-by-step instructions, matching the request for a quick, low-effort biscuit.

question: 5-star ham & tarragon pot pie: how do I make a fuss-free version with pulled ham hock and peas to serve?
llm_answer:
Ham & tarragon pot pie
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 55 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 50 g butter
- 1 onion, chopped
- 2 celery sticks, chopped
- 50 g plain (all-purpose) flour
- 600 ml milk
- 90 g pack pulled ham hock
- Small pack tarragon, leaves only, chopped
- 1 egg, beaten
- 320 g pack ready-rolled puff pastry
- Cooked peas, to serve
- Salt and freshly ground black pepper

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat the oven to 200°C (180°C fan)/gas 6.

2. In a shallow casserole or ovenproof dish, melt the butter over medium heat on the hob.

3. Add the chopped onion and celery and fry gently until softened (do not brown), about 5–8 minutes.

4. Sprinkle in the plain flour and stir to coat the softened vegetables. Cook for 1 minute to cook out the raw flour taste.

5. Slowly add the milk in small splashes, stirring very well after each addition to avoid lumps. Once all the milk is incorporated, bring the mixture to a gentle simmer so it thickens into a smooth sauce.

6. Fold in the pulled ham hock and the chopped tarragon. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Stir in about half of the beaten egg to enrich the filling and help it set a little.

7. Prepare the pastry: cut a circle of puff pastry about 2 cm wider than the top of your dish.

8. Drape the pastry over the dish, tucking and folding the edges to seal the filling inside and form a crust. Use any off-cuts of pastry to cut rough strips or shapes to decorate the top if you like.

9. Brush the exposed pastry with the remaining beaten egg to give a glossy, golden finish.

10. Bake in the preheated oven for about 25 minutes, or until the pastry is golden and crisp and the filling is bubbling.

11. While the pie bakes, cook or reheat your peas (steamed or gently boiled) to serve alongside.

12. Remove the pie from the oven, let it rest for a couple of minutes, then serve slices with the cooked peas.

Notes
- This is a fuss-free, one-dish pot pie—use ready-rolled puff pastry and pre-pulled ham hock to save time.
- Adjust seasoning and tarragon amount to taste; tarragon complements ham beautifully but can be reduced if you prefer a milder herb flavor.
explanation: Directly provides a fuss-free recipe for ham hock and peas pot pie, including ingredients, method, and serving peas.

question: Where can I find a gravity-defying chocolate sweetie cake recipe that uses milk chocolate fingers and sugar-coated tubes for a kids' party?
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Gravity-defying sweetie cake

Difficulty: More effort

Total cooking time: 95 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients:
- 150 ml vegetable oil, plus extra for greasing
- 200 g plain flour
- 8 tbsp cocoa powder
- 2 tsp baking powder
- 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
- 280 g light brown soft sugar
- 200 ml buttermilk
- 100 ml strong coffee or espresso
- 2 tsp vanilla extract
- 2 large eggs
- 2½ × 114 g packs milk chocolate fingers
- 8 tubes of sugar‑coated chocolates (or other sweets)
- 100 g milk chocolate, chopped into small pieces, plus 50 g/2 oz for decorating
- 200 g slightly salted butter, softened
- 400 g icing sugar, sieved
- 4 tbsp cocoa powder
- 2 tbsp milk
- 1 bendy straw
- 2 wooden skewers
- 1 paper bag or sweet packet (see tip)
- Sticky tape

Step-by-step instructions:

1. Preheat and prepare tins
   - Heat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan) / Gas 4.
   - Grease and line two 20 cm cake tins with baking parchment. If your tins are shallow, line the sides to a depth of at least 5 cm.

2. Mix dry ingredients
   - In a bowl, combine the plain flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, bicarbonate of soda, light brown sugar and 1 tsp salt. Break up any lumps in the sugar by squeezing them between your fingers.

3. Mix wet ingredients
   - In a jug, measure the buttermilk, coffee, vegetable oil and vanilla. Add the eggs and whisk until smooth.

4. Combine batter and bake
   - Pour the wet ingredients into the dry and whisk until well combined.
   - Divide the batter evenly between the two prepared tins and bake for 25–30 minutes, until risen and a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean.
   - Cool in the tins for 10 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack, peel off the baking parchment and leave to cool completely.
   - (These sponges can be made up to three days ahead and will stay moist if wrapped in cling film, or you can freeze them for up to two months.)

5. Make the chocolate fudge icing
   - Put 100 g chopped milk chocolate in a heatproof bowl set over a pan of barely simmering water and stir until melted. (Alternatively melt in the microwave, stirring every 20 seconds.)
   - Remove from heat and leave to cool slightly.
   - In another large bowl, mash the 200 g softened butter and 400 g sieved icing sugar with a spatula to combine, then whisk with a hand mixer until smooth (mashing first prevents icing sugar mess).
   - Sift in 4 tbsp cocoa powder, pour in the melted chocolate and add 2 tbsp milk, then mix until smooth.

6. Ice the cake
   - Use roughly half the icing to sandwich the two cakes together on a cake stand or board.
   - Use a palette knife to cover the entire cake with the remaining icing — don’t worry about being too neat.

7. Attach chocolate fingers
   - Straight after icing (while the icing is still soft), press the milk chocolate fingers around the sides of the cake so they stick. The icing will firm up and help hold them in place.

8. Prepare extra chocolate for sticking sweets
   - Melt the remaining 50 g chocolate in the microwave or over a pan of gently simmering water. Leave it to cool until it reaches a spreadable consistency. If it firms up too much, reheat briefly and stir.

9. Build the gravity-defying sweet tower
   - Push one wooden skewer into the centre of the cake. Slip the bendy straw over the skewer — this gives stability. Push 1–2 cm of the straw into the cake.
   - Using a cutlery knife or small palette knife, spread a blob of the melted 50 g chocolate onto a sugar‑coated tube sweet. Starting at the base, stick the sweets to the straw.
   - Work in stages, allowing the chocolate to set a little between layers, and continue building sweets up the straw until it’s completely covered. Stop when you reach the bend in the straw.
   - If the chocolate becomes too firm while you work, warm it briefly until spreadable again.

10. Finish the top
   - Stick the remaining wooden skewer into the top of the straw so it pokes out at an angle. Place the paper bag or sweet packet over the top (you may need a little sticky tape to hold it in place).
   - If any of the straw is still visible, cover it with more sweets.
   - Tip the remaining sweets on top of the cake to flood the surface.

Storage tip:
- Will keep well stored in an airtight tin for 2 days.

Enjoy your gravity-defying sweetie cake — perfect for a kids’ party!
explanation: The answer provides a complete gravity-defying sweetie cake recipe containing milk chocolate fingers and sugar-coated tubes, suitable for a kids' party, matching the user's request.

question: Looking for a dairy-free chocolate cake with rich frosting using 70% dairy-free chocolate and sunflower spread (egg-free, nut-free)?
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Easy vegan chocolate cake

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 55 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients:
- a little dairy-free sunflower spread, for greasing
- 1 large ripe avocado (about 150g)
- 300g light muscovado sugar
- 350g gluten-free plain flour
- 50g good-quality cocoa powder
- 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
- 2 tsp gluten-free baking powder
- 400ml unsweetened soya milk
- 150ml vegetable oil
- 2 tsp vanilla extract
- 85g ripe avocado flesh, mashed
- 85g dairy-free sunflower spread
- 200g dairy-free chocolate, 70% cocoa, broken into chunks
- 25g cocoa powder
- 125ml unsweetened soya milk
- 200g icing sugar, sifted
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- gluten-free and vegan sprinkles, to decorate (optional)

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 160°C (140°C fan)/gas 3. Grease two 20cm sandwich tins with a little dairy-free sunflower spread and line the bases with baking parchment.

2. Put 1 large avocado and 300g light muscovado sugar in a food processor and whizz until smooth.

3. Add 350g gluten-free plain flour, 50g cocoa powder, 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda, 2 tsp gluten-free baking powder, 400ml unsweetened soya milk, 150ml vegetable oil and 2 tsp vanilla extract plus ½ tsp fine salt to the food processor. Process again until you have a velvety, liquid batter.

4. Divide the batter evenly between the two prepared tins and bake for about 25 minutes (or until fully risen and a skewer inserted into the middle comes out clean).

5. Cool the cakes in the tins for 5 minutes, then turn them out onto a wire rack to cool completely.

6. While the cakes cool, prepare the frosting. Beat together 85g ripe mashed avocado flesh and 85g dairy-free sunflower spread with electric beaters until creamy and smooth. Pass this mixture through a sieve and set aside.

7. Melt 200g dairy-free 70% chocolate either over a bowl of simmering water (bain-marie) or in short bursts in the microwave, then allow it to cool for a few minutes.

8. For the cocoa base of the frosting: sift 25g cocoa powder into a large bowl. Bring 125ml unsweetened soya milk to a simmer, then gradually beat it into the cocoa until smooth. Cool for a few minutes.

9. Tip the sieved avocado–sunflower spread mix into the cocoa mixture, then add 200g sifted icing sugar, the melted dairy-free chocolate and 1 tsp vanilla extract. Keep mixing until you have a shiny, thick frosting.

10. Use the frosting to sandwich the two cake layers together and to top the cake. Decorate with gluten-free and vegan sprinkles if you like.

11. Leave the frosted cake to set for about 10 minutes before slicing. The cake can be made up to 2 days ahead.

Enjoy your dairy-free, egg-free, nut-free (uses sunflower spread) chocolate cake with rich 70% chocolate frosting.
explanation: The recipe is dairy-free, egg-free, and nut-free, uses 70% dairy-free chocolate in the frosting, and incorporates sunflower spread as part of the frosting, satisfying the stated criteria.

question: Is there a simple muffin recipe that gives a firm maple-sugar glaze on top (the cracked crust look)?
llm_answer:
Maple-glazed blueberry muffins
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 45 minutes
Calories (kcal): None

Ingredients
- 250g plain flour
- 1 ½ tsp baking powder
- 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
- 140g granulated sugar
- 100g unsalted butter, melted
- 50g buttermilk
- 2 large eggs
- 50g maple syrup, plus 1 1/2 tbsp for the topping
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- 175g blueberries, plus extra for the top
- 3 tbsp icing sugar

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan) / Gas 4. Place paper muffin cases in a muffin tray.
2. In a large bowl, combine the plain flour, baking powder, bicarbonate of soda, granulated sugar and 1/2 tsp salt.
3. In a jug, whisk together the melted unsalted butter, buttermilk, eggs, 50g maple syrup and vanilla extract.
4. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients, add most of the blueberries, and stir briefly to just combine. Do not overmix.
5. Divide the mixture between the muffin cases (an ice-cream scoop helps for even portions).
6. Bake for 22–25 minutes until well risen and a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean. Transfer the muffins to a wire rack.
7. Mix the remaining 1 1/2 tablespoons maple syrup and the icing sugar together with a pinch of salt until smooth.
8. While the muffins are still warm, brush the maple-icing over each muffin. Dot a few extra blueberries on top of each one.
9. Best eaten within a day or two.
explanation: Provides a simple muffin recipe with a maple syrup–based glaze on top and steps to apply it. This directly matches the user's request for a muffin recipe with a firm maple-sugar glaze on top. It does not explicitly state 'cracked crust,' but the glaze method and topping align with the core requirement.

question: Spiced vegan sticky toffee pudding with cinnamon, star anise and cloves — good for serving a crowd?
llm_answer:
Vegan sticky toffee pear pudding
Difficulty: More effort
Total cooking time: 75 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 8 small firm pears (we used Conference)
- 200g golden caster sugar
- 2 cinnamon sticks
- 1 star anise
- 6 cloves
- 1 lemon, zest pared
- 1 orange, zest pared
- Vegan ice cream, to serve (optional)
- 250g pitted dates
- 2 tbsp linseeds
- 300ml unsweetened almond milk
- 200ml vegetable oil, plus extra for greasing
- 175g dark muscovado sugar
- 200g self-raising flour
- 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
- 1 tsp ground mixed spice
- 1/2 tsp salt (for the sponge; included in the method as needed)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Poach the pears and make the syrup:
   - Peel the pears and cut the bottom off each to give a flat base so they will stand upright in the tin. Trim them to a height that will fit snugly in your tin. Use a melon baller or a small knife to scoop out the pips from the base. Roughly chop the pear scraps (discard the pips) and set the scraps aside for the sponge.
   - Tip 200g golden caster sugar, the 2 cinnamon sticks, 1 star anise, 6 cloves, lemon and orange zests and 600ml water into a saucepan large enough to fit all the pears. Bring to the boil, then simmer until the sugar has dissolved.
   - Add the pears, cover with a lid or a piece of baking parchment, and poach gently for 15 minutes, until a knife easily slides into a pear. Leave the pears to cool in the poaching liquid.

2. Make the date mixture for the sponge:
   - Put the 250g pitted dates and 2 tbsp linseeds in a saucepan and add the 300ml unsweetened almond milk. Bring to a gentle simmer, then cook for 2–3 minutes until the dates are soft.
   - Pour the mixture into a food processor and blitz until smooth. Add 200ml vegetable oil and blend again until combined. Scrape the mixture into a bowl and set aside to cool slightly.

3. Prepare the cake batter:
   - Heat the oven to 180°C / 160°C fan / gas 4. Grease and line a 20 x 30 cm baking tin (a loose-bottomed tin if possible) with a strip of baking parchment.
   - Put the dry ingredients in a large mixing bowl: 175g dark muscovado sugar, 200g self-raising flour, 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda, 1 tsp ground mixed spice, and 1/2 tsp salt. Mix well, breaking up any lumps of sugar with your fingers and shaking the bowl a few times to lift any remaining lumps.
   - Add the cooled date and oil mixture and stir well to combine. Fold in the chopped pear scraps you set aside earlier.

4. Assemble and bake:
   - Scrape the cake mixture into the prepared tin and level it. Nestle the poached pears into the batter, standing them straight up so their bottom halves are covered by the batter.
   - Bake for 35–40 minutes until the cake is cooked through. Insert a skewer into the centre — it should come out clean. If there is wet cake mixture on the skewer, return to the oven and bake for an additional 10 minutes, then check again.

5. Finish with the syrup and serve:
   - Meanwhile, bring the pear poaching liquid back to the boil and simmer until reduced to a glossy syrup.
   - When the pudding is cooked, cool for 5–10 minutes, then brush the entire surface with the reduced syrup, saving a little extra to serve alongside.
   - Serve warm, with extra syrup and vegan ice cream if liked.

Enjoy serving this spiced vegan sticky toffee pear pudding — the cinnamon, star anise and cloves in the poaching liquid give it a fragrant warm spice ideal for a crowd.
explanation: The answer provides a complete recipe for a spiced vegan sticky toffee pudding (pear variant) featuring cinnamon, star anise, and cloves, with steps and serving suggestions tailored for entertaining (crowd).

question: No-cook pitta pizzas topped with mint and feta — is this beginner-friendly and fast to assemble?
llm_answer:
Fast feta & aubergine pizzas

Difficulty: Easy

Ingredients:
- 4 pitta breads, white or brown
- 330 g jar roasted aubergines
- 100 g feta cheese, crumbled
- Handful of mint leaves, roughly chopped

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Toast the pitta breads in batches until they are lightly golden and just starting to crisp.
2. Drain the roasted aubergines, reserving some of the oil from the jar.
3. Put half of the drained aubergines into a food processor and whizz until smooth to make an aubergine paste.
4. Spread the aubergine paste evenly over each toasted pitta.
5. Top each pitta with the remaining aubergine slices.
6. Scatter the crumbled feta over the pittas.
7. Sprinkle the chopped mint leaves on top and drizzle with a little of the reserved aubergine oil.
8. Serve immediately.

Total cooking time: 10 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided
explanation: The answer provides a quick, simple recipe for pita pizzas with feta and mint, including step-by-step instructions and a total time of 10 minutes, which aligns with being beginner-friendly and fast to assemble.

question: 5-star savoury baking recipe for pesto and cheese whirls that uses fresh pesto, basil and semi-dried tomatoes — is it difficult and how long does it take?
llm_answer:
Recipe: Cheese & pesto whirls

Difficulty: More effort

Total cooking time: 80 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 450g strong white bread flour, plus a little for dusting
- 7g sachet fast-action dried yeast
- 1 tsp golden caster sugar
- 2 tbsp olive oil, plus a drizzle
- 150g tub fresh pesto
- 240g tub semi-dried tomatoes, drained and roughly chopped
- 100g grated mozzarella (ready-grated is best for this, as it is drier than fresh)
- 50g parmesan (or vegetarian alternative), grated
- Handful basil leaves
- 1½ tsp fine salt
- ~300ml warm water (measure out 300ml and use roughly 280ml first; reserve a little in case you need it)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Mix the dry ingredients:
   - Combine the flour, yeast, sugar and 1½ tsp fine salt in a large mixing bowl, or in the bowl of a tabletop mixer.

2. Make the dough:
   - Measure out 300ml warm water and add roughly 280ml to the flour along with the 2 tbsp olive oil. Start mixing until the ingredients start to clump together into a dough. If the dough seems a little dry, add the remaining water.
   - Once combined, knead for 10 minutes by hand on your work surface, or for 5 minutes on a medium speed in a mixer. The dough is ready when it feels soft, springy and elastic.

3. First prove:
   - Clean the bowl, drizzle in a little oil, then pop the dough back in, turning it over so the sides of the bowl are coated in oil. Cover with some oiled cling film and set aside in a warm place to double in size – this will take 1–3 hours, depending on the temperature.

4. Shape the whirls:
   - Line a baking tray with baking parchment.
   - Uncover the dough and punch it down a couple of times with your fist to knock out the air bubbles. Tip the dough out onto a floured work surface and dust the top with a little flour if it is sticky.
   - Roll the dough out to a rectangle roughly 40 x 30 cm.
   - Spread the fresh pesto evenly over the dough, then scatter the chopped semi-dried tomatoes, both cheeses (mozzarella and parmesan) and the basil leaves over the top.
   - Roll the dough up from one of the longer sides into a long sausage.

5. Cut and prove:
   - Use a sharp knife to cut the rolled dough into 12 even pieces.
   - Place the pieces on the prepared baking tray, cut-side up, in a 3-by-4 formation. Make sure the open end of each roll is tucked in towards the centre of the swirl to prevent them from uncoiling during baking.
   - Leave a little space between each roll for expansion. Loosely cover with oiled cling film and leave to prove for 30 minutes–1 hour until almost doubled in size again. Meanwhile, heat the oven to 200°C / 180°C fan / gas 6.

6. Bake:
   - Uncover the rolls once puffed up. Bake on the middle shelf of the hot oven for 35–40 minutes, until golden brown and the centre looks dry and not doughy.

7. Cool and serve:
   - Remove from the oven and leave to cool for at least 10 minutes before serving.

Notes
- The recipe uses fresh pesto, basil and semi-dried tomatoes as requested.
- The difficulty is listed as "More effort" because of kneading and proving times.
- Although the total-cooking-time field is 80 minutes, actual hands-on and proving/baking times in the method include longer proving (1–3 hours for first prove) plus 30–60 minutes for the second prove and a 35–40 minute bake — allow extra time for proving when planning.
explanation: The answer provides a complete recipe using fresh pesto, basil and semi-dried tomatoes and directly states the difficulty ('More effort') along with time estimates (total time and proving/baking durations), addressing the user's questions.

question: 5-star easy cookie recipe using golden syrup, light muscovado sugar and dried apricots — what ingredients and baking time are needed?
llm_answer:
Fruity flapjack cookies

Difficulty: Easy

Ingredients
- 125g jumbo oats
- 150g softened butter
- 100g light muscovado sugar
- 1 egg
- 1 tbsp golden syrup
- ½ tsp vanilla extract
- 100g self-raising flour
- 100g mixed dried fruit or raisins
- 75g dried apricots, finely chopped
- 50g desiccated coconut
- ½ tsp ground cinnamon (optional)
- Pinch of salt

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat the oven to 180°C / 160°C fan / Gas 4. Scatter the oats over a baking tray and bake for 20 minutes, turning once, until lightly browned. Remove from the oven and set aside to cool.
2. Tip the softened butter and light muscovado sugar into a bowl and beat with an electric whisk for about 2 minutes until fluffy.
3. Crack in the egg and add the golden syrup and vanilla extract, then beat until completely combined.
4. Add the self-raising flour, all the dried fruit (including the chopped dried apricots), desiccated coconut, cinnamon (if using), the toasted oats and a pinch of salt. Beat again until everything is combined and you have a thick dough. You can use the dough straightaway or cover and chill for up to two days.
5. Line two baking sheets with baking parchment. Arrange six large spoonfuls of dough on each sheet, spaced well apart to allow for spreading.
6. Bake for 15 minutes (or 18–20 minutes if the dough is fridge-cold) until the cookies have spread and are brown at the edges but soft in the middle.
7. Leave the cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack and leave to cool completely.

Total cooking time: 60 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not specified
explanation: The provided recipe includes all requested ingredients (golden syrup, light muscovado sugar, dried apricots) and explicit baking times (15 minutes, or 18–20 minutes if the dough is fridge-cold) plus total time, thus directly answering the user's question about ingredients and baking duration.

question: Simple rainbow cookie recipe using 2 egg yolks and golden caster sugar for a kids' bake
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Rainbow cookies
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 45 minutes
Calories: 168 kcal

Ingredients:
- 175g softened butter
- 50g golden caster sugar
- 50g icing sugar
- 2 egg yolks
- 2 tsp vanilla extract
- 300g plain flour
- zest and juice 1 orange
- 140g icing sugar, sifted
- sprinkles, to decorate

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Heat the oven to 200°C / 180°C fan / gas 6.
2. In a bowl, mix the softened butter, golden caster sugar, icing sugar, egg yolks and vanilla with a wooden spoon until creamy.
3. Mix in the plain flour in 2 batches, then stir in the orange zest.
4. Roll the dough into about 22 walnut-size balls and place them on baking sheets.
5. Bake for 15 minutes or until golden, then leave the cookies to cool.
6. Meanwhile, mix the 140g sifted icing sugar with enough orange juice to make a thick, runny icing.
7. Dip each biscuit (cookie) half into the icing, then immediately into the sprinkles to decorate.
8. Dry the cookies on a wire rack before serving.
explanation: The answer provides a rainbow cookies recipe that uses 2 egg yolks and golden caster sugar, is simple/easy, and suitable for a kids' bake; includes ingredients and steps.

question: How do I make a quick, easy strawberry mousse with mascarpone and a gingernut biscuit crunch in about 25 minutes?
llm_answer:
Quick cheat's strawberry mousse
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 25 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 500g strawberries, hulled and halved (quarter any larger ones)
- 1 lemon, zested and juiced
- 100g caster sugar
- 150ml mascarpone
- 300ml double cream
- 1 tbsp vanilla bean paste
- 4 gingernut biscuits, crushed
- Small handful of pistachios, roughly chopped (optional)
- Freeze-dried strawberries, crushed (optional)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Put the strawberries, lemon juice, sugar and 2 tbsp water in a large pan over a medium heat. Cook for about 5 minutes until the fruit has softened. Scrape the mixture into a bowl and leave to cool slightly.

2. Reserve some of the cooked strawberry mixture: tip about 300g of it into a blender (keep the rest for topping later). Blitz the 300g until smooth, then pass the purée through a sieve into a jug to remove seeds and pulp.

3. In a large bowl, whisk the mascarpone to soften it. Add the double cream, vanilla bean paste and lemon zest, then whisk again until the mixture is just starting to thicken.

4. Fold the sieved strawberry purée into the mascarpone and cream mixture until combined. If you prefer, you can swirl rather than fully fold to create layers of compote through the mousse.

5. Spoon or pipe the mousse into glass tumblers or serving dishes. Top each with some of the reserved strawberry compote you set aside earlier.

6. Sprinkle over the crushed gingernut biscuits and, if using, scatter chopped pistachios and crushed freeze-dried strawberries for extra texture and color.

7. Chill if you have time — the mousse will keep chilled for up to a day. Serve chilled.

Notes
- This is a quick, no-fuss version that comes together in about 25 minutes.
- Optional toppings (pistachios, freeze-dried strawberries) add crunch and color but are not essential.
explanation: Directly provides a quick (about 25 minutes) strawberry mousse recipe with mascarpone and crushed gingernut biscuits, including ingredients and step-by-step instructions.

question: What's a good brownie recipe that blends cardamom and caramel for a rich, moreish chocolate treat?
llm_answer:
Chai caramel chocolate brownies
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 55 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 200g salted butter, plus extra for the tin
- 200g dark chocolate, roughly chopped
- 3 eggs
- 200g caster sugar
- 100g plain flour
- 40g cocoa powder
- ½ tbsp sea salt flakes
- 1 tsp cardamom pods, seeds crushed
- ¼ tsp allspice
- 1 tsp ground cinnamon
- ¼ tsp ground cloves
- ½ tsp ground ginger
- 200g canned caramel

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan)/gas 4. Butter a 20cm square cake tin and line it with two strips of baking parchment.

2. Melt the butter and dark chocolate together in a heatproof bowl set over a pan of gently simmering water (ensure the bowl doesn’t touch the water), or melt in 20-second bursts in the microwave. Stir until smooth and leave to cool slightly.

3. Make the chai caramel: in a bowl mix the 200g canned caramel with the sea salt flakes, crushed cardamom seeds, allspice, ground cinnamon, ground cloves and ground ginger. Stir until the caramel has loosened and the spices are evenly incorporated.

4. Put the eggs and caster sugar in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the whisk attachment and beat for about 5 minutes until the mixture is pale and thick. (Alternatively, use an electric whisk.)

5. Fold the slightly cooled melted chocolate and butter into the whipped eggs and sugar using a spatula. Once combined, add the plain flour and cocoa powder and mix gently until there are no streaks of flour and the batter is even.

6. Pour the brownie batter into the prepared tin and spread evenly. Spoon or drizzle the chai caramel over the top of the batter. Using a teaspoon, gently swirl the caramel into the batter to create marbling—don’t overmix.

7. Bake for 25–30 minutes. The brownies are done when the edges are set and there is a slight wobble in the center. If they wobble a lot, bake an additional 5 minutes. The finished brownies should have a shiny, papery crust on top and the sides should just be beginning to come away from the tin.

8. Leave the brownies to cool completely in the tin. Once cool, remove and slice into 16 squares.

9. Store in an airtight container for up to three days.
explanation: The answer provides a complete brownie recipe featuring cardamom and caramel (chai caramel), matching the request for a rich, chocolate brownie.

question: How do I make an easy vegan lemon cake with vegetable oil and a lemon icing in about 45 minutes?
llm_answer:
Recipe: Vegan Lemon Cake with Lemon Icing

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 45 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 100 ml vegetable oil, plus a little extra to grease the tin
- 275 g self-raising flour
- 200 g golden caster sugar
- 1 tsp baking powder
- 1 lemon — zest of the lemon, and the juice divided (half for the cake, half for the icing)
- 170 ml cold water
- 150 g icing (confectioners') sugar

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat the oven to 200°C (180°C fan) / Gas 6. Grease a 1 lb (small) loaf tin with a little vegetable oil and line it with baking parchment.
2. In a large bowl, combine 275 g self-raising flour, 200 g golden caster sugar, 1 tsp baking powder and the zest of 1 lemon. Mix to distribute evenly.
3. Add 100 ml vegetable oil, the juice of half the lemon, and 170 ml cold water to the dry ingredients. Stir until the batter is smooth and lump-free.
4. Pour the batter into the prepared loaf tin and smooth the top.
5. Bake in the preheated oven for about 30 minutes, or until a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean.
6. Remove the cake from the oven and let it cool in the tin for 10 minutes. Then lift it out using the parchment and transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.
7. Meanwhile, make the lemon icing: sift 150 g icing sugar into a bowl. Add the remaining lemon juice (from the other half of the lemon) little by little and mix until you reach a thick but pourable consistency — thick enough to coat the top without running off completely. (If the icing becomes too thin, add a little more icing sugar; if too thick, add a few drops of lemon juice.)
8. Once the cake is fully cooled, pour the icing over the top and allow it to set before slicing and serving.

Enjoy your easy vegan lemon loaf!
explanation: The answer provides a complete vegan lemon cake recipe using vegetable oil and a lemon icing, with a total time of about 45 minutes, matching the user's request.

question: Anzac biscuits with butter and caster sugar — about 118 kcal per biscuit? Is this an easy snack to bake?
llm_answer:
Anzac biscuits
Difficulty: Easy
Total time: 35 minutes
Calories: 118 kcal (per biscuit)

Ingredients
- 85 g porridge oats
- 85 g desiccated coconut
- 100 g plain flour
- 100 g caster sugar
- 100 g butter, plus extra butter for greasing
- 1 tbsp golden syrup
- 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
- 2 tbsp boiling water (for the bicarb)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan) / gas 4. Grease baking sheets with a little extra butter.
2. Put the oats, desiccated coconut, plain flour and caster sugar in a large bowl and mix together.
3. Melt the butter in a small pan, then stir in the golden syrup.
4. Dissolve the bicarbonate of soda in 2 tablespoons of boiling water, then stir this into the melted butter and golden syrup mixture.
5. Make a well in the centre of the dry ingredients and pour in the butter/golden syrup/bicarb mixture. Stir gently until the dry ingredients are just incorporated.
6. Using dessertspoonfuls of the mixture, place mounds on the prepared baking sheets, leaving about 2.5 cm (1 in) between them to allow for spreading.
7. Bake in batches for 8–10 minutes, or until golden.
8. Transfer the biscuits to a wire rack to cool. They will crisp as they cool.

Enjoy your easy homemade Anzac biscuits!
explanation: [Directly answers both parts: provides the 118 kcal per biscuit and confirms the snack is easy to bake, with a full recipe and step-by-step instructions.]

question: 5-star salmon and leek pastry recipe — how do I get a flaky filo crust with a creamy leek filling?
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Salmon & Leek pastry

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 50 minutes

Calories (kcal): None provided

Ingredients:
- 4 leeks, trimmed and finely chopped
- 25 g butter
- 100 g full-fat crème fraîche or cream cheese
- 6 sheets filo pastry
- 2 skinless salmon fillets
- melted butter (for brushing)
- seasoning (salt & pepper) to taste

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Heat the oven to 200°C (fan 180°C) / gas 6.
2. Put the chopped leeks into a large saucepan with 3 tablespoons water and a couple of knobs of the 25 g butter. Cover and cook for about 10 minutes until the leeks are tender.
3. Remove the leeks from the pan and allow to cool. Once cooled, stir the leeks together with the 100 g crème fraîche (or cream cheese) and season to taste.
4. To assemble the parcels: brush a sheet of filo pastry with melted butter, then lay two more sheets on top, brushing melted butter between each layer so you have three buttered sheets in a stack.
5. Place a salmon fillet in the centre of the stacked pastry, season the fillet, then spoon over half the leek mixture.
6. Fold the ends of the pastry over the top, pull up the sides and scrunch the pastry together to enclose the filling and form a parcel. Repeat the process with the remaining filo, salmon fillet and leek mixture to make the second parcel.
7. Brush both parcels all over with melted butter.
8. Place the parcels on a lightly greased baking sheet and bake in the preheated oven for 20–25 minutes, until the pastry is browned and crisp.
9. Serve hot, for example with a green salad.

Enjoy your flaky filo parcels with creamy leek filling and salmon!
explanation: The answer provides a complete recipe that directly explains how to achieve a flaky filo crust (layering filo with melted butter) and includes a creamy leek filling (leeks with crème fraîche/cream cheese), along with steps to assemble and bake the pastry.

question: How do I make easy vegan chocolate ice cream using canned coconut milk and cornflour in about 45 minutes?
llm_answer:
Vegan chocolate ice cream
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 45 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 2 x 400 g cans coconut milk (not light)
- 175 g caster sugar
- 50 g cocoa powder
- 100 g vegan dark chocolate, chopped
- 1 tsp sea salt flakes
- 1 tbsp vanilla extract or 1 heaped tsp vanilla bean paste
- 2 tbsp cornflour

Step-by-step instructions
1. Pour most of the coconut milk into a saucepan, leaving a small splash (about 2–3 tbsp) in a small bowl for the cornflour.  
2. Add the caster sugar, cocoa powder, chopped vegan dark chocolate, sea salt flakes and vanilla to the saucepan with the coconut milk. Heat gently over low–medium heat for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sugar has dissolved and the chocolate has melted. Do not let it boil vigorously.  
3. While the chocolate mixture heats, mix the 2 tbsp cornflour with the reserved splash of coconut milk in the small bowl until completely smooth with no lumps.  
4. Pour the cornflour slurry into the hot coconut-chocolate mixture. Cook for another 5–10 minutes, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens to a pourable custard consistency.  
5. Strain the custard into a bowl to remove any lumps, then cover and leave to cool to room temperature.  
6. If you have an ice cream maker: pour the cooled custard into the machine and churn for 20–30 minutes until you have a soft-scoop ice cream. Transfer to a freezerproof, sealable container and freeze until firm (or up to three months). Before serving, leave to stand 10 minutes at room temperature for easier scooping.  
7. If you don’t have an ice cream maker: pour the cooled custard into a wide-based plastic tub or dish and place in the freezer. For about 3 hours, freeze but stir vigorously every 20 minutes to break up ice crystals and create a smooth, soft ice cream. Once you reach a soft-scoop texture, transfer to a freezerproof, sealable container and freeze until ready to serve. Let stand 10 minutes at room temperature before scooping.  

Enjoy your easy vegan chocolate ice cream!
explanation: The answer provides a complete, step-by-step recipe for easy vegan chocolate ice cream using canned coconut milk and cornflour, with a total time of about 45 minutes and practical instructions.

question: Where can I find a highly rated (5-star) free-from butterscotch pie recipe that's soy- and gluten-free?
llm_answer:
Free-from butterscotch pie
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 25 minutes (plus chilling time: chill 4–6 hours until set)
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 200g dark brown soft sugar
- 2 tbsp golden syrup
- 625ml canned coconut milk
- 1 tbsp vanilla bean paste or vanilla extract
- 4 tbsp cornflour
- 2 tbsp vegan margarine (from a hard block, not a tub)
- 95g thick coconut yogurt or vegan soured cream
- 1 pre-baked 22cm gluten-free and vegan pastry case, or a 400g pack gluten-free, vegan shortcrust pastry, rolled out and baked in a 22cm pie dish following pack instructions

Step-by-step instructions
1. In a large saucepan, combine the 200g dark brown soft sugar, 2 tbsp golden syrup, 1/4 tsp salt, and 250ml of the canned coconut milk. Bring the mixture to the boil over a medium heat so it becomes syrupy.

2. Meanwhile, in a large heatproof bowl whisk together the remaining coconut milk (the other 375ml), 1 tbsp vanilla bean paste or extract, and 4 tbsp cornflour until smooth.

3. When the syrupy coconut mixture comes to the boil, slowly drizzle it into the bowl with the coconut/vanilla/cornflour mixture in a steady stream, whisking continuously to combine. Pour the combined mixture back into the saucepan and simmer over medium heat, whisking continuously until thick, about 5–7 minutes.

4. Remove the pan from the heat and whisk in 2 tbsp vegan margarine and 95g thick coconut yogurt or vegan soured cream until smooth.

5. Pour the butterscotch filling into the prepared pre-baked gluten-free pastry case. Cover the surface with a circle of baking parchment (to prevent a skin forming) and chill the pie in the refrigerator for 4–6 hours, until set.

6. Keep chilled and consume within up to two days.

Notes
- Use a gluten-free, vegan pastry case as specified. Check product labels if you must also avoid soy, since some vegan margarines or processed pastry products can contain soy ingredients.
explanation: The answer provides a gluten-free, vegan 'free-from' butterscotch pie recipe and notes about potential soy ingredients, but it does not address finding a 5-star rated (highly rated) recipe or explicitly confirm soy-free status for all ingredients.

question: Easy vegan apple and almond cake using oat milk and dairy-free spread — how do I make this?
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Vegan apple cake

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 100 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not specified

Ingredients:
- 150g dairy-free spread, melted, plus extra for the tin
- 300ml oat milk
- 1 tbsp lemon juice
- 350g self-raising flour, plus 1 tbsp to coat the apples
- 100g caster sugar
- 100g light brown soft sugar
- 1 tsp baking powder
- 1 tsp almond extract
- 300g Granny Smith apples, peeled, cored and chopped into 2cm cubes
- 2 tbsp flaked almonds

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan) / gas 4. Use the dairy-free spread to butter a 20cm deep cake tin and line the base with baking parchment.
2. Pour the oat milk into a jug, add the lemon juice and leave to sit for 5 minutes at room temperature so it thickens slightly.
3. In a large bowl, put the self-raising flour, caster sugar, light brown sugar and baking powder.
4. Pour the thickened oat milk mixture and the almond extract into the dry ingredients. Add the melted dairy-free spread and ½ tsp salt. Beat everything together using an electric whisk until combined.
5. Tip the chopped apples into a second large bowl, sprinkle over the extra 1 tbsp flour and toss to coat the apple pieces (this helps prevent them sinking).
6. Fold the coated apples through the cake batter using a spatula, then spoon the mixture into the prepared tin. Sprinkle the flaked almonds evenly over the top.
7. Bake in the centre of the oven for 1 hour to 1 hour 20 minutes, or until the cake is golden and firm to the touch (a skewer should come out clean or with only a few moist crumbs).
8. Leave to cool for a few minutes in the tin, then either serve warm or turn out onto a wire rack and leave to cool completely.
9. Store once cool in an airtight container for up to three days.
explanation: Provides a complete vegan apple cake recipe with oat milk and dairy-free spread, including ingredients and step-by-step instructions.

question: Simple microwave banana pudding using self-raising flour and butter — no oven dessert?
llm_answer:
Microwave banana pudding
Difficulty: Easy

Ingredients:
- 100g butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
- 2 ripe bananas
- 100g light muscovado sugar
- 100g self-raising flour
- 2 tsp ground cinnamon
- 2 eggs
- 2 tbsp milk
- Icing sugar, toffee sauce and ice cream, to serve (optional)

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Lightly grease a 1‑litre microwave‑safe baking dish with a little extra butter.
2. Put the 100g softened butter in the baking dish and microwave on High for 30 seconds–1 minute, until melted.
3. Peel 1½ of the bananas and mash them into the melted butter in the dish until well combined.
4. Add the 100g light muscovado sugar, 100g self‑raising flour, 2 tsp ground cinnamon, 2 eggs and 2 tbsp milk to the mashed banana and butter. Mix together well until smooth.
5. Slice the remaining ½ banana and arrange the slices over the top of the mixture.
6. Return the dish to the microwave and cook on High for about 8 minutes, until the pudding is cooked through and has risen.
7. Serve warm. Dust with icing sugar and drizzle with toffee sauce, with a scoop of ice cream if you like.

Total cooking time: 20 minutes
Calories: 474 kcal
explanation: It provides a complete microwave banana pudding recipe using self-raising flour and butter, matching the query's 'no oven' dessert requirement, with ingredients and step-by-step instructions.

question: Top-rated (5-star) pitta recipe using harissa aubergine and boiled eggs — where can I find it?
llm_answer:
Recipe: Egg & veggie pittas
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 35 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not specified

Ingredients
- 1 aubergine, cut into thick rounds
- 1½ tbsp olive oil
- 1 tbsp harissa
- 2 eggs
- 1 tbsp red wine vinegar
- 2 tsp agave nectar or golden caster sugar
- 1 raw beetroot, grated
- 1 large carrot, peeled and julienned
- ½ small red onion, very finely sliced
- 4 tbsp 0% fat Greek yogurt
- 1 tbsp chopped dill
- 1 garlic clove, crushed
- 2 wholemeal pitta breads
- Salt and pepper, to season

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat the oven to 220°C (200°C fan) / gas 7. Arrange the aubergine slices on a baking sheet, season with salt and pepper, brush with the olive oil and bake for 15 minutes.
2. After 15 minutes, turn the aubergine slices, spread them with the harissa and bake for a further 5 minutes. Set aside any remaining aubergine after baking.
3. Meanwhile, carefully lower the eggs into a pan of boiling water. Turn down the heat and simmer for 10 minutes for hard-boiled eggs. Remove, run under cold water to cool, peel and set aside.
4. In a bowl, mix the red wine vinegar and the agave nectar (or golden caster sugar) with some seasoning. Add the grated beetroot, julienned carrot and finely sliced red onion and toss to make the salad.
5. In another bowl, mix together the Greek yogurt, chopped dill, crushed garlic and seasoning to make the dill-yogurt sauce.
6. Toast the pittas and split them in half. Slice the boiled eggs.
7. Fill each pitta with slices of egg, the spicy harissa aubergine rounds and some of the beetroot salad. Spoon in the dill-yogurt sauce.
8. Serve with any remaining aubergine, salad and yogurt on the side.
explanation: The answer provides a pitta recipe that uses harissa aubergine and boiled eggs, matching the requested dish. It does not explicitly mention a 5-star rating or a source link, but it directly offers the relevant recipe.

question: How can I make a light-textured, lower-gluten rye loaf with honey and optional caraway seeds?
llm_answer:
Rye bread
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 50 minutes
Calories: 170 kcal

Ingredients
- 200 g rye flour, plus extra for dusting
- 200 g strong white or wholemeal flour
- 7 g sachet fast-action dried yeast
- ½ tsp fine salt
- 1 tbsp honey
- 250 ml warm water (more if needed)
- 1 tsp caraway seed (optional)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Tip the rye and white/wholemeal flours, the yeast and the salt into a large mixing bowl. Stir to combine.
2. In a jug, mix the honey into about 250 ml warm water. Pour the liquid into the bowl with the dry ingredients and mix to form a dough.
   - Note: rye flour absorbs a lot of water and can feel quite dry. If the dough looks too dry, add a little more warm water, a tablespoon at a time, until you have a soft dough.
3. Tip the dough onto your work surface and knead for about 10 minutes until smooth. Because rye contains less gluten than white flour, the dough won’t feel as springy as a conventional white loaf.
4. Place the dough in a well-oiled bowl, cover with cling film and leave to rise in a warm place for 1–2 hours, or until roughly doubled in size.
5. Dust a 2 lb / 900 g loaf tin with flour.
6. Tip the risen dough back onto your work surface and knead briefly to knock out any large air bubbles. If using caraway seeds, work them into the dough now.
7. Shape the dough into a smooth oval loaf and place it into the prepared tin. Cover the tin with oiled cling film and leave to rise somewhere warm for a further 1–1.5 hours, or until doubled in size.
8. Heat the oven to 220°C (200°C fan) / Gas 7.
9. Remove the cling film, dust the surface of the loaf with rye flour and slash a few incisions on an angle.
10. Bake for about 30 minutes until dark brown and hollow-sounding when tapped on the bottom.
11. Transfer the loaf to a wire cooling rack and leave to cool for at least 20 minutes before slicing and serving.
explanation: The answer provides a complete recipe for a light-textured rye loaf using honey and includes an option to add caraway seeds, addressing the lower-gluten aspect of rye and the requested texture.

question: Easy rainbow zebra cake recipe for a birthday — sponge with blue and pink food colouring, buttercream and sprinkles, total time about 80 minutes?
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Rainbow zebra cake

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 80 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients:
- 375g salted butter, softened, plus extra for the tin
- 375g golden caster sugar
- 6 large eggs, at room temperature
- 375g self-raising flour
- 1½ tsp baking powder
- 150ml milk
- Blue food colouring
- Pink food colouring
- Sprinkles, to decorate

For the buttercream:
- 250g salted butter, softened
- 400g icing sugar, sifted
- Seeds from 1 vanilla pod (or 1 tsp vanilla extract)
- 100g full-fat cream cheese

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 180°C / 160°C fan / gas 4. Butter and line three 20cm loose-bottomed sandwich cake tins with baking parchment.

2. Make the sponge batter: Beat the 375g softened butter and 375g golden caster sugar together in a stand mixer or with an electric whisk for 5–8 minutes, until light and fluffy.

3. Add the eggs: Whisk in the 6 eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition.

4. Fold in dry ingredients and milk: Gently fold in the 375g self-raising flour and 1½ tsp baking powder, and add the 150ml milk to loosen the batter to a soft dropping consistency.

5. Divide and colour the batter: Divide the mixture between three bowls (weigh for accuracy if you like). Colour one bowl of batter blue and another pink — start with a little colouring and add more until you reach the desired depth. Leave the third bowl uncoloured (plain).

6. Create the zebra/rainbow effect in the tins: Have the three prepared cake tins ready. For each tin, spoon a heaped tablespoon of batter into the centre — blue batter into one tin, pink into the second, and plain into the third. Working quickly, keep alternating dollops of different coloured batter on top of each previous dollop. Don’t wait for the batter to settle; the weight of the layers will spread them. Gently tap and shake the tins to even out the mixture.

7. Bake: Bake the cakes in the centre of the oven for 25–30 minutes, or until the cakes are firm to the touch and a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean.

8. Cool: Turn the cakes out top-side down onto wire racks straightaway, then leave to cool completely.

9. Make the buttercream: Put 250g softened butter, 400g sifted icing sugar and the vanilla pod seeds into a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment (or use a bowl and electric whisk). Beat for about 5 minutes until fluffy and aerated. Add 100g full-fat cream cheese and beat briefly until just combined — do not overbeat.

10. Assemble the cake: Place one cooled cake on a cake stand or serving plate and spread about 2 tablespoons of the buttercream on top. Repeat with the second cake, then place the third on top.

11. Finish the icing: Spread a smooth layer of the remaining buttercream over the top and sides of the cake using a large palette knife. For a casual “naked” finish, leave some slightly less-iced spots if you like.

12. Decorate: Top the cake with sprinkles and candles as desired.

13. Storage: Will keep in an airtight tin for three days.

Enjoy your rainbow zebra birthday cake!
explanation: Gives a full Rainbow zebra cake recipe matching the request (blue and pink sponge, buttercream, sprinkles), with total time listed as 80 minutes.

question: Can I prep these sweet potato and ginger parcels in 30 minutes and cook in 30 minutes — any tips for using feuilles de brick and butter?
llm_answer:
Sweet potato & ginger parcels

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 60 minutes

Calories: 65 kcal

Ingredients:
- 400g sweet potato
- 50g melted butter, plus a knob extra
- 1 red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
- 4 spring onions, finely sliced
- Thumb-size piece ginger, grated
- ½ a 190g pack feuilles de brick pastry
- Few pinches cinnamon

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Cook the sweet potatoes until tender — either microwave or oven-cook them.  
2. While the potatoes cook, melt a knob of butter in a pan. Fry the chopped red chilli for about 30 seconds, then add the white parts of the spring onions and the grated ginger and fry for 1 minute.  
3. Scoop the flesh from the cooked sweet potatoes, discarding the skins, and mash the flesh into the pan with the fried chilli, onion and ginger. Season to taste, then stir in the green parts of the spring onions.  
4. Heat the oven to 200°C / 180°C fan / gas 6. Unroll a sheet of feuille de brick pastry and cut three 6 cm strips from the middle; discard the leftover pastry. Brush each strip with melted butter.  
5. Place a spoonful of the sweet potato mix at one end of a buttered strip and fold the strip up in a side-to-side motion to make a triangular parcel, ensuring the filling is completely sealed in. Arrange the parcels on a baking sheet, brush the tops with more melted butter, and repeat until all the filling is used.  
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 20 minutes, or until the parcels are crisp and golden.  
7. Dust with a pinch of cinnamon and serve.
explanation: The answer provides a full recipe using feuilles de brick and butter and includes practical tips (brushing with melted butter, forming and sealing parcels). However, it does not directly confirm whether you can complete prep in 30 minutes and cook in 30 minutes; it lists a total time of 60 minutes, which partially addresses but does not satisfy the exact timing question.

question: Easy weeknight recipe: sweet potato & rosemary soup that uses 750g sweet potato and makes garlic toast with 8 slices of bread?
llm_answer:
Sweet potato & rosemary soup with garlic toasts
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 30 minutes
Calories (kcal): not provided

Ingredients
- 2 tsp olive oil, plus extra for brushing
- 1 onion, chopped
- 3 garlic cloves
- 750 g sweet potato, peeled and cubed
- 1 L vegetable stock
- 2 rosemary sprigs
- 8 slices bread (ciabatta is good)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat 2 tsp olive oil in a large saucepan over a medium heat.
2. Add the chopped onion and fry until soft (about 5–7 minutes).
3. Crush 2 of the garlic cloves and add them to the onion. Fry for 1 minute more.
4. Stir in the cubed sweet potato, then pour in the vegetable stock to cover. Bring to the boil.
5. Strip the leaves from one rosemary sprig and add the leaves to the pan.
6. Reduce the heat and simmer for about 10 minutes, until the sweet potato is soft.
7. While the soup simmers, heat the oven to 200°C (fan 180°C) / gas 6.
8. Place the 8 slices of bread on a baking sheet and brush lightly with olive oil.
9. Slice the remaining garlic clove in half, then rub the cut side over the oiled bread. Rub the bread with the leaves from the second rosemary sprig as well. Season the bread slices.
10. Bake the bread for about 10 minutes, until crisp and golden.
11. Return to the soup: use a hand blender to roughly purée the soup to your desired texture. If it’s too thick, add a splash of the hot cooking water or extra stock to loosen.
12. Taste and season the soup well with salt and pepper.
13. Pour the soup into warmed bowls and serve immediately with the garlic toasts.
explanation: The answer provides a complete recipe for sweet potato & rosemary soup that uses 750 g sweet potato and includes garlic toast made with 8 slices of bread, matching the user's request.

question: How can I make a 4-star easy garlic bread nachos dish in under 30 minutes?
llm_answer:
Recipe title: Garlic bread nachos

Difficulty: Easy

Ingredients:
- 3 ready-made garlic baguettes
- 90g lighter mature cheddar, grated
- 3 spring onions, finely sliced
- 30g bag tortilla chips, crunched a few times to roughly crush
- 90g soured cream
- handful coriander leaves

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Cut through the baguettes to separate all the slices, discarding the end pieces.
2. Pile the bread slices on top of your biggest baking sheet, all overlapping, as you would with tortillas for nachos. Scatter over most of the cheese, spring onions and crushed tortilla chips as you layer, finishing with a final layer of these toppings. (If you’re preparing ahead, you can cover the tray with cling film and chill until ready to cook.)
3. Heat oven to 200°C / 180°C fan / gas 6. Bake for 15 minutes until the cheese has melted and the bread is golden and crisp.
4. Loosen the soured cream with enough water to make a more drizzly topping, then spoon over the nachos and sprinkle with some coriander.
5. Serve while everything is still hot and melted.

Total cooking time: 25 minutes

Calories (kcal): None provided
explanation: The answer provides a complete, easy garlic bread nachos recipe with total time under 30 minutes, including ingredients and step-by-step instructions.

question: Easy, kid-friendly Father's Day cupcakes (rated 4) — can I make them extra chocolatey by swapping a bit of flour for cocoa?
llm_answer:
Recipe: Father's Day cupcakes
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 20 minutes
Calories: 492 kcal

Ingredients
- 150g pot natural yogurt
- 3 eggs, beaten
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- 175g golden caster sugar
- 140g self-raising flour (swap 1 tbsp of the flour for cocoa powder if you want them extra chocolatey)
- 100g ground almond
- 175g unsalted butter, melted
- 100g chocolate (milk or dark)
- 140g unsalted butter (for the frosting)
- 140g icing sugar

Step-by-step instructions

1. Prepare
- Line a 12-hole muffin tin with paper cases and heat the oven to 190°C (170°C fan) / gas 5.

2. Make the batter
- In a jug, mix the natural yogurt, beaten eggs and vanilla extract.
