- Put the dry ingredients (self-raising flour — with 1 tbsp swapped for cocoa powder if using — ground almond and golden caster sugar), plus a pinch of salt, into a large bowl and make a well in the middle.
- Add the yogurty mix and the melted 175g butter, and quickly fold in with a spatula or metal spoon — don’t overwork the batter.

3. Bake
- Spoon the mixture into the paper cases (they will be quite full) and bake for 18–20 minutes or until golden, risen and springy to the touch.
- Cool in the tin for a few minutes, then lift the cupcakes onto a wire rack to cool completely.
- Store in an airtight container for up to 3 days or freeze as soon as possible.

4. Chocolate frosting
- Melt the 100g chocolate in the microwave on High for 1½ minutes, stirring halfway. Leave to cool.
- Beat the 140g butter and 140g icing sugar in a large bowl until creamy.
- Beat the cooled melted chocolate into the butter-and-sugar mixture.
- Cover and chill the frosting (it can be stored up to one month). Up to 48 hours before serving (or the day before if it’s very hot), bring the frosting back to room temperature, then spread over the cooled cupcakes.
- Decorate (the original suggests adding chocolate buttons). Keep the finished cupcakes cool and out of direct sunlight.
explanation: The answer directly addresses making the cupcakes extra chocolatey by swapping 1 tablespoon of flour for cocoa powder, and provides a complete recipe including this modification.

question: Beginner-friendly biscuit recipe: simple jammy biscuits with egg and caster sugar — total cook time 22 minutes?
llm_answer:
Simple jammy biscuits
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 22 minutes
Calories: 170 kcal

Ingredients
- 200g self-raising flour
- 100g caster sugar
- 100g butter
- 1 egg, lightly beaten
- 4 tbsp strawberry jam

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat the oven to 190°C (170°C fan) / gas 5. Rub the flour, sugar and butter together until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs. Alternatively, you can do this in a food processor.
2. Add enough of the lightly beaten egg to bring the mixture together to form a stiff dough. Flour your hands and shape the dough into a tube about 5 cm in diameter. Cut the tube into 2 cm-thick slices and place them on a large baking sheet, spacing them out as the mixture will spread when baking.
3. Make a small indentation in the middle of each slice with the end of a wooden spoon and drop about 1 teaspoon of jam into the centre of each.
4. Bake for 10–15 minutes until slightly risen and just golden. Cool on a wire rack before serving.
explanation: The answer directly provides a beginner-friendly jammy biscuits recipe using egg and caster sugar and explicitly lists a total cooking time of 22 minutes, matching the user's request.

question: 3-hour vegan simnel cake with mixed dried fruit and glacé cherries — is there a recipe for Easter?
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Vegan Simnel Cake

Difficulty: More effort

Total cooking time: 180 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients:
- 200 ml soya milk
- 1 lemon, zested and ½ juiced
- 500 g marzipan
- Icing sugar, for dusting
- 250 g dairy-free spread, plus extra for the tin
- 250 g mixed dried fruit (we used sultanas, raisins and candied peel)
- 75 g glacé cherries, roughly chopped
- 1 orange, zested and juiced
- 200 g light brown soft sugar
- 200 g plain flour
- 75 g ground almonds
- 1 tsp baking powder
- ½ tsp ground ginger
- ½ tsp ground cinnamon
- 1 tsp mixed spice
- 2 tsp vanilla bean paste
- 25 g apricot jam, warmed, plus extra for sticking the marzipan balls to the cake

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan)/gas 4.
2. Mix the soya milk with the ½ lemon juice in a jug and set aside for a few minutes to thicken.
3. Cut 150 g of the marzipan from the larger block. Lightly dust a work surface with icing sugar and roll the 150 g marzipan out until it is just slightly smaller than the base of a 23 cm cake tin. Set aside.
4. Using the dairy-free spread, butter a 23 cm springform cake tin and line with a double layer of baking parchment.
5. In a large bowl, mix the mixed dried fruit, lemon zest, chopped glacé cherries, and orange zest and juice together, tossing a few times until well combined.
6. In a separate bowl, beat the dairy-free spread with the light brown soft sugar until pale using an electric whisk.
7. Add the plain flour, ground almonds, baking powder, ground ginger, ground cinnamon, mixed spice, and vanilla bean paste to the creamed mixture and mix briefly.
8. Tip in the milk mixture and whisk until you have a smooth batter.
9. Fold the fruit mixture (including any juice in the bowl) and a pinch of salt into the batter until well combined — don’t worry if the batter looks slightly curdled.
10. Spoon half the batter into the prepared tin and gently smooth the surface with the back of a spoon. Place the rolled marzipan round on top of this layer.
11. Spoon over the remaining batter to cover the marzipan, smooth the surface, and level.
12. Bake at 180°C for 30 minutes, then reduce the oven temperature to 150°C (130°C fan)/gas 2 and bake for a further 1 hour 45 minutes to 2 hours, or until a skewer inserted into the cake comes out clean and the cake is well risen and firm.
13. Carefully remove the cake from the tin and leave to cool completely on a wire rack.
14. Brush the cooled cake with the warmed 25 g apricot jam.
15. Cut a 200 g piece from the remaining marzipan and roll it out on a surface dusted with icing sugar. Cut out a 23 cm circle using the base of the cake tin as a guide. Use the rolling pin to lift the marzipan circle over the cake and gently press it onto the surface (the apricot jam will help it stick).
16. Divide the remaining marzipan into 11 pieces and roll into balls. Use a little extra warmed apricot jam to stick the balls around the edge of the cake — these represent the 12 apostles (minus Judas).
17. If desired, use a kitchen blowtorch briefly and carefully to slightly burnish the marzipan decorations until just golden (take care not to burn).

Serving and storage:
- Cut into slices to serve.
- Will keep for up to two weeks in an airtight container.
explanation: Provides a complete vegan simnel cake recipe associated with Easter, including ingredients and step-by-step instructions.

question: Simple puff pastry apple tart for morning tea or dessert that’s rated 5 stars and easy for beginners?
llm_answer:
Flat apple & vanilla tart
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 30 minutes
Calories: 356 kcal

Ingredients
- 375 g pack puff pastry (preferably all-butter)
- 5 large eating apples (e.g. Cox's, russets or Elstar)
- Juice of 1 lemon
- 25 g butter, cut into small pieces
- 3 tsp vanilla sugar or 1 tsp vanilla extract
- 1 tbsp caster (superfine) sugar
- 3 rounded tbsp apricot conserve

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat the oven to 220°C (fan 200°C) / Gas 7. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
2. Roll out the puff pastry and trim it to a round about 35 cm across. Transfer the pastry round to the prepared baking sheet.
3. Peel, core and thinly slice the apples. Toss the apple slices in the lemon juice so they don’t brown.
4. Arrange the apple slices over the pastry, leaving a 2 cm border all the way around. Gently curl up the pastry edges slightly to help contain the juices.
5. Dot the apple surface with the small pieces of butter. Sprinkle the apples and pastry with the vanilla sugar (or vanilla extract) and the caster sugar.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15–20 minutes, until the apples are tender and the pastry is crisp and golden.
7. Meanwhile, warm the apricot conserve so it becomes brushable (microwave briefly or warm in a small saucepan).
8. When the tart is out of the oven, brush the warmed apricot conserve over the apples and the pastry edge for a glossy finish.
9. Serve hot or warm — excellent with vanilla ice cream or crème fraîche.
explanation: The answer provides a complete, simple puff pastry apple tart recipe marked as Easy and suitable for morning tea or dessert. While it does not explicitly include a 5-star rating, it addresses the core request for a simple, beginner-friendly puff pastry apple tart.

question: Vegan cherry & almond brownies with glacé cherries and vanilla extract — beginner-friendly 5-star recipe?
llm_answer:
Recipe: Vegan cherry & almond brownies

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 65 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 80g vegan margarine, plus extra for greasing
- 2 tbsp ground flaxseed
- 120g dark chocolate
- ½ tsp coffee granules
- 125g self-raising flour
- 70g ground almond
- 50g cocoa powder
- ¼ tsp baking powder
- 250g golden caster sugar
- 1½ tsp vanilla extract
- 70g glacé cherries (rinsed and halved)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat the oven to 170°C (150°C fan) / gas mark 3½. Grease and line a 20cm square tin with baking parchment.
2. Combine the ground flaxseed with 6 tbsp water and set aside for at least 5 minutes to thicken (this acts as the egg replacer).
3. In a saucepan, melt the dark chocolate, coffee granules and vegan margarine with 60ml water over low heat. Once melted and combined, allow the mixture to cool slightly.
4. In a bowl, put the self-raising flour, ground almond, cocoa powder, baking powder and ¼ tsp salt. Stir to remove any lumps.
5. Using a hand whisk, mix the golden caster sugar into the melted chocolate mixture and beat well until smooth and glossy, ensuring the sugar is fully dissolved.
6. Stir the flaxseed mixture and the vanilla extract into the chocolate mixture, then fold in the halved glacé cherries.
7. Add the flour-almond-cocoa mixture to the wet ingredients. It will be very thick — stir until just combined.
8. Spoon the batter into the prepared tin and smooth the top.
9. Bake for 35–45 minutes, until a skewer inserted into the middle comes out clean with moist crumbs (do not expect it to be completely dry).
10. Allow the brownies to cool completely in the tin, then cut into squares.
11. Store in an airtight container and eat within 3 days.
explanation: The answer provides a complete vegan cherry & almond brownie recipe featuring glacé cherries and vanilla extract, with an easy (beginner-friendly) difficulty level. It aligns with the user's request for a beginner-friendly recipe and includes the requested ingredients, though it does not explicitly state a 5-star rating.

question: Quick no-bake 'white forest' rocky road recipe with biscuits, almonds and desiccated coconut — what ingredients and yield do I need?
llm_answer:
White forest rocky road
Difficulty: Easy

Ingredients
- 100g butter
- 500g white chocolate, chopped
- 200g biscuits (digestives or malted milk work well)
- 50g blanched almonds, roughly chopped
- 200g dried or glacé cherries, roughly chopped
- 50g mini marshmallows (ensure vegetarian, if needed)
- 15g desiccated coconut

Yield
- One 20cm square tin (cut into squares to serve)

Total cooking time
- 15 minutes (plus chilling time — see instructions)

Calories (kcal)
- Not provided

Step-by-step instructions
1. Line a 20cm square baking tin with baking parchment.
2. Melt the butter and chopped white chocolate together in a heatproof bowl set over a pan of simmering water (ensure the bowl doesn’t touch the water), or melt in the microwave in 20-second bursts, stirring between bursts, until smooth.
3. Take the biscuits: cut five or six triangles from a few biscuits with a sharp knife to make “trees.” Put the off-cuts in a bowl and bash the remaining biscuits into rubble.
4. Tip the chopped almonds and most of the cherries and marshmallows into the bowl with the bashed biscuits.
5. Pour the melted chocolate and butter mixture over the biscuit/nut/cherry/marshmallow mix and fold gently until everything is coated in chocolate.
6. Tip the mixture into the prepared tin and smooth the top.
7. Press the row(s) of biscuit “trees” into one end of the rocky road. Sprinkle the reserved cherries/marshmallows over the top, and scatter the desiccated coconut to resemble snow.
8. Transfer the tin to the fridge and chill for about 2 hours, or until solid.
9. Remove from the tin using the parchment, then cut into squares to serve.
explanation: The answer provides the requested ingredients and yield for the quick no-bake 'white forest' rocky road recipe.

question: Can I make these kofta burgers in about 50 minutes and serve them in 8 pittas?
llm_answer:
DIY kofta burgers
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 50 minutes
Calories: 295 kcal per serving

Ingredients
- 1 kg lamb mince
- 2 onions, coarsely grated
- 1 garlic bulb, cloves broken and finely chopped or grated
- 6 tbsp garam masala
- Bunch coriander, chopped (optional)
- 1 tbsp chilli sauce, plus extra to serve
- 8 pitta breads
- 4 tomatoes, halved and sliced
- Half a red cabbage, shredded
- 1 red onion, sliced (optional)
- Small pot plain yogurt
- Good pinch of salt

Step-by-step instructions
1. Prepare the mix: Tip the lamb mince into a large bowl. Add the coarsely grated onions, chopped/grated garlic, garam masala, chopped coriander (if using), 1 tbsp chilli sauce and a good pinch of salt.
2. Combine thoroughly: Roll up your sleeves and use your hands to squelch and squash everything together through your fingers until completely mixed and evenly combined.
3. Shape the burgers: Pat the mixture into 16 small burgers (this yields two kofta burgers per pitta for 8 pittas).
   - Tip: These can be frozen for up to 1 month at this stage, or chilled up to a day ahead if you want to save time on the day.
4. Preheat the grill: Heat the grill to its highest setting and position the top shelf ready.
5. Cook the burgers: Lay the burgers in a single layer on a baking tray (you may need to do this in batches depending on tray size). Grill for 5–6 minutes on each side until browned and cooked through.
6. Prepare accompaniments while burgers cook: Slice the tomatoes, shred the red cabbage, slice the red onion (if using), and have the plain yogurt and extra chilli sauce ready.
7. Warm the pittas: Lightly warm or toast the 8 pitta breads if you prefer them warm and slightly crisp.
8. Assemble and serve: Pile the cooked kofta burgers onto a platter with the tomatoes, shredded cabbage, sliced onion, yogurt and extra chilli sauce. Let everyone construct their own pitta: place two small kofta burgers into each pitta with desired salad and a dollop of yogurt or a drizzle of chilli sauce.

Enjoy your kofta burgers in pitta — makes 8 filled pittas.
explanation: The answer provides a 50-minute total cooking time and yields 8 pittas with kofta burgers, directly addressing the user's plan to make them in about 50 minutes and serve in 8 pittas.

question: How can I make a moist vegan chocolate cake using mashed avocado and 70% dairy-free chocolate chunks?
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Easy vegan chocolate cake

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 55 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients:
- A little dairy-free sunflower spread, for greasing
- 1 large ripe avocado (about 150 g)
- 300 g light muscovado sugar
- 350 g gluten-free plain flour
- 50 g good-quality cocoa powder
- 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
- 2 tsp gluten-free baking powder
- 400 ml unsweetened soya milk
- 150 ml vegetable oil
- 2 tsp vanilla extract
- 85 g ripe avocado flesh, mashed (for the frosting)
- 85 g dairy-free sunflower spread (for the frosting)
- 200 g dairy-free chocolate, 70% cocoa, broken into chunks (some used melted for the frosting)
- 25 g cocoa powder (for the frosting)
- 125 ml unsweetened soya milk (for the frosting)
- 200 g icing sugar, sifted (for the frosting)
- 1 tsp vanilla extract (for the frosting)
- Gluten-free and vegan sprinkles, to decorate (optional)

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 160°C (140°C fan) / gas 3. Grease two 20 cm sandwich tins with a little dairy-free sunflower spread and line the bases with baking parchment.
2. In a food processor, put 1 large ripe avocado (about 150 g) and 300 g light muscovado sugar. Whizz until smooth.
3. To the processor bowl add 350 g gluten-free plain flour, 50 g cocoa powder, 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda, 2 tsp gluten-free baking powder, 400 ml unsweetened soya milk, 150 ml vegetable oil, 2 tsp vanilla extract and ½ tsp fine salt. Process again until you have a velvety, liquid batter.
4. Divide the batter evenly between the two prepared tins and bake for about 25 minutes, or until the cakes are fully risen and a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean.
5. Cool the cakes in the tins for 5 minutes, then turn them out onto a rack to cool completely.
6. While the cakes cool, prepare the frosting. Beat together 85 g ripe avocado flesh and 85 g dairy-free sunflower spread with electric beaters until creamy and smooth. Pass the mixture through a sieve and set aside.
7. Melt 200 g dairy-free chocolate (70% cocoa), either over a bowl of simmering water (bain-marie) or in short bursts in the microwave, then let it cool for a few minutes.
8. Sift 25 g cocoa powder into a large bowl. Bring 125 ml unsweetened soya milk to a simmer, then gradually beat it into the cocoa until smooth. Cool for a few minutes.
9. Into the cooled cocoa mixture, tip the avocado–sunflower spread mix, 200 g sifted icing sugar, the melted dairy-free chocolate and 1 tsp vanilla extract. Keep mixing until you have a shiny, thick frosting.
10. Use the frosting to sandwich the two cake layers together and to top the cake. Decorate with gluten-free and vegan sprinkles if desired.
11. Leave the decorated cake to set for about 10 minutes before slicing. The cake can be made up to 2 days ahead. Enjoy.
explanation: The answer provides a complete vegan chocolate cake recipe that uses mashed avocado and 70% dairy-free chocolate chunks, with steps and frosting, directly addressing the user's request.

question: What's the nutritional info per cookie for the vintage chocolate chip cookies (about 121 kcal and 6.3g fat)?
llm_answer:
Vintage chocolate chip cookies
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 25 minutes
Calories (per cookie): 121 kcal

Ingredients
- 150g salted butter, softened
- 80g light brown muscovado sugar
- 80g granulated sugar
- 2 tsp vanilla extract
- 1 large egg
- 225g plain flour
- ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
- ¼ tsp salt
- 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat the oven to 190°C (fan 170°C)/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.
2. Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.
3. Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg until combined.
4. Sift 225g plain flour, ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¼ tsp salt into the bowl and mix in with a wooden spoon until just combined.
5. Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.
6. Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.
7. Bake for 8–10 minutes until the edges are light brown and the centres are still slightly soft when pressed.
8. Leave the cookies on the tray for a couple of minutes to set, then transfer them to a cooling rack to cool completely.
explanation: The answer provides the calories per cookie (121 kcal) but does not include the requested fat content (6.3 g).

question: Looking for an easy, small-batch microwave chocolate brownie recipe that uses peanut butter and a few teaspoons of jam—any suggestions?
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Microwave brownies

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 15 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients:
- 75 g butter, plus a little extra for greasing
- 50 g peanut butter
- 1 egg
- 25 g cocoa powder
- 50 g plain flour
- 100 g sugar
- A few teaspoons of jam

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Add the 75 g butter and 50 g peanut butter to a microwave-safe bowl. Cook on High for 30 seconds to melt.
2. Remove from the microwave and stir thoroughly to combine. Allow the mixture to cool slightly.
3. Add the egg to the cooled butter/peanut butter mixture and stir to combine.
4. Grease a second microwaveable round dish (about 15 cm wide) with a little butter and line it with cling film.
5. Tip the peanut butter mixture into the lined dish.
6. Sieve in the 25 g cocoa powder and 50 g plain flour, then add the 100 g sugar. Mix gently to form a thick, sticky paste. Smooth the top with the back of a large spoon.
7. Using a teaspoon, make small crater-holes in the top of the brownie mixture and fill each generously with a few teaspoons of jam (it will melt and bubble down when cooked).
8. Microwave on High for 3–4 minutes.
9. Remove and leave to cool for 15 minutes (the brownies will continue to cook as they cool). Serve and enjoy.
explanation: The answer provides a complete, easy, small-batch microwave brownie recipe that uses peanut butter and jam as described in the question.

question: How do I make a savoury tart using slow-roasted vine tomatoes and plenty of gruyère — what flavor and texture should I expect?
llm_answer:
Slow‑roasted tomato & gruyère tart

Difficulty: More effort
Total cooking time: 85 minutes
Calories: 496 kcal

Ingredients
- 200g plain flour, plus extra for dusting
- 100g butter, cut into small pieces
- 50g grated gruyère (or vegetarian alternative)
- 500g smallish vine tomatoes, halved
- 1 tbsp olive oil
- handful basil leaves, torn
- 3 tbsp pesto (choose a vegetarian one)
- 2 eggs
- 150ml single cream
- 150ml milk
- 100g grated gruyère (or vegetarian alternative)
- handful black olives

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat the oven to 140°C (120°C fan)/gas 1. Arrange the halved tomatoes, cut-sides up, over a baking sheet. Brush them lightly with the olive oil and put a little torn basil on top of each tomato half. Roast the tomatoes gently for 1½ hours until they are semi-dried. Remove the tomatoes from the oven and increase the oven temperature to 190°C (170°C fan)/gas 5.

2. Make the pastry: tip the flour into a food processor with the butter and whizz until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs. Add the 50g grated gruyère and 2–3 tbsp cold water and pulse until the dough comes together. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and briefly knead.

3. Roll out the pastry and line a 25cm flan tin (there’s no need to trim off the excess at this stage). Line the pastry with greaseproof paper and fill with baking beans. Blind-bake for 15 minutes, then remove the paper and baking beans and continue cooking until the pastry is crisp and light golden. Using a small, sharp knife, carefully trim off any excess pastry.

4. Spread the pesto over the base of the baked pastry case.

5. Lightly whisk the 2 eggs, then whisk in the single cream and milk. Season with salt and pepper, then stir in the 100g grated gruyère.

6. Pour the egg and cheese mixture into the pastry case. Arrange the slow-roasted tomatoes over the top, cut-sides up. Scatter the handful of black olives over the tart.

7. Bake the tart at 190°C (170°C fan)/gas 5 for 25–30 minutes until puffed and golden. Remove from the oven and leave to cool slightly before serving.
explanation: The text provides a complete recipe for a slow-roasted tomato and Gruyère tart (ingredients and step-by-step instructions). While it doesn't explicitly summarize flavor and texture, the method implies expected flavors (sweet-tart tomatoes, cheesy, pesto notes) and textures (crisp pastry, creamy filling, semi-dried tomatoes) aligned with the user's request.

question: Simple energy balls with dates and coconut oil for a nutritious on-the-go snack — what's the recipe?
llm_answer:
Recipe name: Energy balls with dates

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 10 minutes

Calories: 113 kcal (per ball, approximate)

Ingredients:
- 50 g soft dried apricot
- 100 g soft dried dates
- 50 g dried cherries
- 2 tsp coconut oil
- 1 tbsp toasted sesame seeds

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Put the apricots, dates and dried cherries into a food processor.
2. Whizz until the mixture is very finely chopped and comes together into a sticky mass.
3. Tip the mixture into a bowl. Using your hands, work the coconut oil into the mix until evenly distributed.
4. Shape the mixture into walnut-sized balls.
5. Roll each ball in the toasted sesame seeds to coat.
6. Store the energy balls in an airtight container and keep handy for a quick on-the-go energy snack.
explanation: Directly answers the request by providing a complete recipe for energy balls using dates and coconut oil (with additional ingredients for flavor and texture), including ingredients and step-by-step instructions.

question: Any highly rated (5-star) vegan banana cupcakes that include vegan dark chocolate chips and a peanut butter element?
llm_answer:
Recipe title: Vegan cupcakes with banana & peanut butter

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 45 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided

Makes: about 16 cupcakes

Ingredients
- 240 g self-raising flour
- 140 g golden caster sugar
- 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
- ½ tsp salt
- 240 g egg-free mayonnaise
- 2 large (or 3 small) ripe bananas, mashed
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- 25 g vegan dark chocolate chips
- 80 g vegan margarine
- 250 g icing sugar
- 25 ml vegan milk (we used almond milk)
- 2 tbsp smooth peanut butter

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat the oven to 170°C (150°C fan) / gas 3½. Line a muffin tin with 16 paper cases.
2. In a bowl, combine the self-raising flour, golden caster sugar, ½ tsp salt and 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda.
3. In a separate bowl or jug, mix together the 240 g egg-free mayonnaise, mashed bananas and 1 tsp vanilla extract.
4. Pour the wet mixture into the dry ingredients and gently mix with a spoon until just combined. (Do not overmix — the cupcakes will be heavy if overworked.)
5. Spoon the batter evenly into the 16 cases.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for about 20 minutes, until a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean.
7. When the cupcakes come out of the oven, immediately sprinkle the 25 g vegan dark chocolate chips over the tops — they will melt and then harden again as they cool, creating a chocolate topping. Leave cupcakes to cool.
8. While cupcakes cool, make the peanut-butter icing: in an electric mixer, combine the 80 g vegan margarine and 250 g icing sugar. Add the 25 ml vegan milk and mix on a slow speed until fully combined. Increase the mixer speed and beat for a further 3 minutes to lighten the icing.
9. Stir 2 tbsp smooth peanut butter into the icing until evenly distributed.
10. Once cupcakes are cooled, pipe or spread the peanut-butter icing on top of each cake.
11. Store the cupcakes in an airtight container and eat within 2 days.
explanation: Provides a vegan banana cupcake recipe with vegan dark chocolate chips and peanut butter, but does not indicate any 5-star rating.

question: Can I make peanut butter cookies using 200g peanut butter and 175g caster sugar — beginner-friendly recipe?
llm_answer:
Peanut butter cookies
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 27 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 200g peanut butter (crunchy or smooth)
- 175g golden caster sugar
- 1 large egg
- 1/4 tsp fine table salt

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan) / gas mark 4. Line 1–2 large baking trays with baking parchment.
2. Measure the peanut butter and sugar into a bowl. Add 1/4 tsp fine table salt and mix well with a wooden spoon.
3. Add the egg and mix again until the mixture comes together into a dough.
4. Break off cherry-tomato-sized chunks of dough and place them well spaced apart on the prepared trays.
5. Press each cookie down gently with the back of a fork to flatten them a little (this also creates the classic criss-cross pattern if you like).
6. (Optional) The shaped cookies can be frozen for up to 2 months — bake from frozen, adding an extra 1–2 minutes to the cooking time.
7. Bake for about 12 minutes, until the edges are golden and the centers are still a bit paler.
8. Cool the cookies on the trays for 10 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.
9. Store in a cookie jar for up to 3 days.
explanation: The answer provides a complete beginner-friendly peanut butter cookie recipe using 200 g peanut butter and 175 g caster sugar, including ingredients and step-by-step instructions.

question: Is there a flourless, egg-white-only cookie called 'Forgotten Cookies' made with golden caster sugar and pecans?
llm_answer:
Forgotten cookies
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 30 minutes
Calories: 66 kcal (per cookie)

Ingredients:
- 2 large egg whites
- 120 g golden caster sugar
- 120 g pecans, roughly chopped
- 150 g dark chocolate (at least 70% cocoa solids), roughly chopped
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- Pinch of salt

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 180°C / gas 4 (160°C fan). Line two baking sheets with foil.
2. In a large, clean bowl, whisk the egg whites with a pinch of salt until stiff and dry.
3. Gradually whisk the golden caster sugar into the egg whites a little at a time, until the mixture is thick and glossy (a meringue).
4. Tip in the chopped pecans and chopped dark chocolate, add the vanilla extract, and gently fold them into the meringue with a large metal spoon.
5. Spoon heaped teaspoonfuls of the meringue mixture, spaced apart, onto the lined baking sheets.
6. Put the baking sheets in the oven, then turn the oven off. Leave the cookies in the oven for at least 3 hours (or overnight) until the oven is completely cold — this dries them to the right texture.
7. Carefully peel the cookies from the foil once cold. Store in an airtight tin; they will keep for 3–4 days.

Enjoy your flourless, egg-white-only Forgotten cookies made with golden caster sugar and pecans.
explanation: The answer provides a recipe for 'Forgotten cookies' that are flourless, use egg whites, and include golden caster sugar and pecans, directly addressing the question.

question: Any 4-star recipes for a salted honey and chocolate tart served with crème fraîche and crunchy honeycomb?
llm_answer:
Salted honey fudge & chocolate tart
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 95 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 500g pack sweet shortcrust pastry
- 3 tbsp cocoa, plus extra for rolling and dusting
- 2 tsp clear honey
- ½ tsp good-quality sea salt
- Honeycomb, crumbled, to serve (optional)
- Crème fraîche or single cream, to serve
- 140g set honey
- 140g butter, diced
- 150ml double cream
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- 400g dark chocolate, broken into chunks
- 300ml double cream

Step-by-step instructions
1. Make the chocolate pastry: Dice the pastry into chunks and put in a food processor. Sift over the 3 tbsp cocoa, drizzle over the 2 tsp clear honey, then pulse to combine into a chocolate pastry. (If you don’t have a food processor, rub the ingredients together until they form a dough.) Roll out the dough on a lightly cocoa-dusted work surface to a size large enough to line a 23cm loose-bottomed tart tin with a little overhang. Cover and chill for 30 minutes.

2. Blind-bake the tart case: Heat the oven to 200°C/180°C fan/gas 6. Scrunch up a big sheet of baking parchment and use it to line the tart tin. Fill with baking beans and bake for 15–20 minutes until sandy and the sides are firm. Remove the beans and paper, then bake for a further 5–15 minutes until the base is really biscuity. Trim off the overhang and cool the tart case.

3. Make the salted honey fudge layer: Put the 140g set honey, 140g butter (diced) and 150ml double cream into a small pan and warm gently until the butter has completely melted. Bring to a gentle simmer and bubble, stirring, for 4–5 minutes until more golden-coloured and thickened. Stir in ¼–½ tsp good-quality sea salt (to taste), then pour the fudge into the cooled tart case. Chill for 30 minutes to set.

4. Make the chocolate topping: Put the 400g dark chocolate and 300ml double cream in a heatproof bowl set over a pan of barely simmering water (or use short bursts in the microwave). Gently melt, stirring occasionally, until smooth and combined. Remove from heat and cool for about 5 minutes.

5. Assemble the tart: Pour the melted chocolate mixture gently over the set honey fudge layer in the tart case, covering it evenly. Chill the tart until fully set and ready to serve.

6. Serve: Remove the tart from the fridge about 10 minutes before serving to soften slightly. Dust lightly with cocoa and scatter with crumbled honeycomb, if using. Serve with dollops of crème fraîche or a jug of single cream.

Enjoy your salted honey fudge & chocolate tart with crunchy honeycomb and crème fraîche.
explanation: The answer provides a salted honey fudge & chocolate tart recipe that includes crème fraîche and (crunchy) honeycomb, matching the dish described. However, it does not specify a 4-star rating as requested.

question: Is there a 'more effort' rainbow layer cake suited to the Easy birthday cakes category with around 105 minutes prep time?
llm_answer:
Rainbow layer cake
Difficulty: More effort
Total cooking time: 125 minutes
Calories (kcal): None provided

Ingredients
- 340g unsalted butter, softened, plus extra for the tins
- 340g caster sugar
- 6 large eggs
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- 340g self-raising flour
- 1 tsp baking powder
- 2 tbsp milk
- 400g caramel or lemon curd (your choice)
- For the Swiss meringue buttercream:
  - 5 egg whites
  - 375g caster sugar
  - 500g unsalted butter, cubed and softened
  - 3 tsp vanilla extract
- Food colouring gels (for Pride-style colours the recipe suggests: red, orange, yellow, green, dark blue, purple, light pink, baby blue, brown and black)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Prepare the tins and oven
   - Butter three 20cm round cake tins and line their bases with baking parchment.
   - Heat the oven to 190°C (170°C fan) / Gas 5.

2. Make the sponge batter
   - Beat 340g softened unsalted butter and 340g caster sugar together in a large bowl until light and smooth.
   - Gradually beat in the 6 large eggs until combined, then mix in 1 tsp vanilla extract.
   - Fold in 340g self-raising flour and 1 tsp baking powder until fully combined.
   - Stir in 2 tbsp milk to loosen the batter.

3. Bake the sponges
   - Divide the mixture between the three prepared tins.
   - Bake the sponges for about 20 minutes, until golden and a skewer inserted into each centre comes out clean.
   - Leave to cool in the tins for 10 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

4. Make the Swiss meringue buttercream
   - Put 5 egg whites and 375g caster sugar in a heatproof bowl set over a small pan of gently simmering water (ensure the bowl does not touch the water).
   - Whisk for about 3–4 minutes, until the sugar has dissolved and the mixture is warm.
   - Remove from the heat and transfer to the bowl of a stand mixer (or use an electric whisk). Whisk on medium-high speed for about 10 minutes until you have a thick, glossy meringue.
   - Gradually whisk in the softened butter, 1 tablespoon at a time, until fully incorporated and the buttercream is fluffy.
   - Whisk in 3 tsp vanilla extract.

5. Assemble the cake (first fill and crumb coat)
   - Place one sponge on a plate or cake stand. Top it with 3–4 tbsp of the buttercream and spread, making it slightly thicker at the edge.
   - Spoon half of the caramel or lemon curd over the buttercream on the middle part of the cake — do not spread it to the edges.
   - Add the second sponge and repeat with buttercream and the remaining caramel/curd.
   - Top with the final sponge.
   - Smooth a thin layer of buttercream around the outside of the cake to form a crumb coat.
   - Chill the cake in the fridge for at least 45 minutes.

6. Final smooth coat and chill
   - After chilling, smooth another layer of buttercream around the cake using a palette knife to fully cover the sponge. Reserve about half of the buttercream for decoration.
   - Return the cake and the reserved buttercream to the fridge for another 45 minutes to 1 hour to firm up.

7. Colour the buttercream and decorate
   - Divide the remaining buttercream between 11 small bowls. Mix a different gel colouring into 10 of them, leaving the 11th bowl white.
   - Put each colour into a separate piping bag (or cut a ~1cm hole in the end of each bag or fit a round nozzle).
   - Pipe one row of buttercream blobs in alternating colours from top to bottom around the cake. Use a teaspoon or small palette knife to very lightly smear each blob of frosting away from you.
   - For the second row, choose the colour next in sequence to the adjacent colour and pipe over the thinnest part of the smeared blob. Continue piping around, following this pattern to create a swirl effect of colours around the sides.
   - Repeat the same piping-and-smear technique on top of the cake, this time smearing the icing in towards the middle until the top is covered.

8. Serve and store
   - Once decorated, the cake is ready to slice and serve.
   - Store in an airtight container for up to three days.

Notes
- The recipe uses a Swiss meringue buttercream which requires working with warm egg whites over simmering water and a good whisking time—plan your timing accordingly.
- If you prefer fewer colours, adjust the number of bowls and piping bags as desired; the instructions use 10 coloured bags plus one white for a vivid multi-colour finish.
explanation: Provides a rainbow layer cake recipe, which matches the 'rainbow layer cake' concept, but is labeled 'More effort' and shows a total time of 125 minutes (not around 105 minutes) and not in the Easy category, so it does not fully satisfy the user's criteria.

question: Quick 3-ingredient strawberry mousse recipe with double cream—no cooking and ready in 15 minutes?
llm_answer:
Easy strawberry mousse
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 15 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 400g strawberries
- 100g caster sugar
- 300ml double cream

Step-by-step instructions
1. Choose four of the best-looking strawberries and set these aside to finish the mousse.
2. Hull and roughly chop the rest of the strawberries.
3. Tip the chopped strawberries and the caster sugar into a blender or food processor and blitz until smooth.
4. Whisk the double cream to stiff peaks.
5. Reserve roughly 4 tablespoons of the strawberry purée in a small dish, then fold the remaining purée through the whipped cream until the mixture is an even shade of pink.
6. Divide the mousse between four small serving glasses or ramekins. Spoon the reserved purée into each glass/ramekin before or under the mousse as you prefer.
7. Chill for at least 1 hour. (Will keep chilled for up to a day.)
8. Just before serving, halve the reserved strawberries and use these to decorate the mousse.
explanation: The answer provides a 3-ingredient, no-cook strawberry mousse using double cream, aligning with the requested format. However, it requires chilling for at least 1 hour, so it is not actually ready in 15 minutes as asked.

question: Simple 4-star chocolate caramel cake recipe with Lindt-style caramel chocolate and cocoa — what ingredients are needed?
llm_answer:
Chocolate caramel cake
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 50 minutes
Calories: 597 kcal

Ingredients
- 300g butter, plus extra for greasing
- 300g light muscovado sugar
- 3 large eggs
- 1½ tsp baking powder
- 85g cocoa powder
- 225g plain flour
- 225ml soured cream
- 300ml pot double cream
- 5 tbsp dulce de leche or caramel sauce
- 25g caramel flavoured chocolate, finely chopped (we used Lindt)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan) / Gas 4. Lightly grease 2 x 23cm loose-bottom cake tins and line each with a circle of baking parchment.
2. In a large bowl, beat together the 300g butter and 300g light muscovado sugar until pale and creamy.
3. Add the 3 eggs one at a time, beating well between each addition.
4. Stir in 1½ tsp baking powder, 85g cocoa powder and one third of the 225g plain flour. Mix well to combine.
5. Stir in half (about 112–115ml) of the 225ml soured cream.
6. Alternate adding the remaining flour and soured cream, mixing until just combined—do not overmix.
7. Divide the batter between the prepared tins and smooth the surfaces.
8. Bake for about 30 minutes, or until the cakes are firm to the touch and a skewer inserted into the centres comes out clean.
9. Leave the cakes to cool in the tins for 5 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely.
10. When ready to assemble, whip the 300ml double cream with 2 tbsp of the dulce de leche until soft peaks form.
11. Place one cake layer on a serving plate and spread with half the whipped caramel cream. Drizzle over some of the remaining dulce de leche.
12. Top with the second cake layer, then spread the remaining whipped cream on top.
13. Sprinkle the finely chopped 25g caramel-flavoured chocolate over the top. Chill the cake until ready to serve.
explanation: Provides the full list of ingredients for the requested simple 4-star chocolate caramel cake recipe, including the Lindt-style caramel chocolate and cocoa.

question: How can I get light, fluffy texture in gluten-free vanilla cupcakes using gluten-free baking powder?
llm_answer:
Gluten-free cupcakes

Difficulty: Easy

Ingredients:
- 175g unsalted butter, softened
- 175g caster sugar
- 3 eggs, beaten
- 1 tsp vanilla bean paste
- 175g gluten-free self-raising flour
- ½ tsp gluten-free baking powder
- Pinch of salt

For the buttercream:
- 150g unsalted butter, softened
- 300g icing sugar
- 1 tsp vanilla bean paste

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Heat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan) / Gas 4. Line a 12-hole cupcake tin with paper or silicone cases.
2. Put the 175g softened butter and 175g caster sugar in a large bowl and beat with an electric whisk until light and creamy.
3. Pour in the beaten eggs a little at a time, mixing well after each addition to maintain emulsion and avoid curdling.
4. Beat in 1 tsp vanilla bean paste.
5. Sift or fold in the 175g gluten-free self-raising flour, ½ tsp gluten-free baking powder and a pinch of salt until well combined. Do not overmix.
6. Spoon the mixture evenly between the cases.
7. Bake for 15–20 minutes until the tops are golden and firm to the touch at the edges.
8. Leave the cupcakes to cool in the tin for 15 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before icing.
9. For the buttercream: In a clean large bowl, beat 150g softened butter with an electric whisk until pale and fluffy.
10. Add 300g icing sugar one spoonful at a time, mixing as you go, then beat in 1 tsp vanilla bean paste until smooth and pipeable.
11. Transfer the buttercream to a piping bag fitted with a round or star nozzle and pipe generous swirls on top of each cooled cupcake.

Total cooking time: 50 minutes

Calories (kcal): not specified
explanation: The answer provides a gluten-free vanilla cupcake recipe that uses gluten-free baking powder and includes techniques (creaming butter and sugar, not overmixing, proper leavening) aimed at achieving a light, fluffy texture.

question: Kid-friendly Peach Melba pop pies with raspberries and canned peach slices — is there an easy 50-minute recipe?
llm_answer:
Peach Melba Pop Pies
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 50 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 200 g raspberries (set 6 plump raspberries aside)
- 410 g can peach slices in fruit juice, drained and chopped
- 1 tbsp cornflour
- 1 tbsp honey
- 2 x 320 g shortcrust pastry sheets
- 1 egg, beaten
- 150 g icing sugar
- Freeze-dried raspberries or sprinkles, optional

Step-by-step instructions
1. Set 6 plump raspberries aside for decoration. Tip the remaining raspberries into a bowl and add the chopped drained peaches. Toss the fruit together.

2. In a small bowl mix the cornflour and honey to make a smooth paste. Pour this paste over the fruit and combine so the filling is evenly coated.

3. Unroll the shortcrust pastry sheets. Use a pizza wheel (or knife) to cut out 6 rectangles from each sheet.

4. Take one pastry rectangle and position it so the long side is nearest you. Fold it in half like a book to create a fold down the middle, then open it out.

5. Spoon some of the fruit filling onto one half of the rectangle, leaving a border of about 1 cm around the edge. Brush the beaten egg around the edges of the filling half.

6. Fold the pastry back over to encase the filling and press the edges together. Use a fork to seal the edges all the way around. Brush the top of each pie with more beaten egg and poke a few small air holes in the top with the fork.

7. Repeat steps 4–6 with the remaining pastry and filling to make the rest of the pop pies. Arrange the pop pies on a baking sheet lined with baking parchment.

8. Chill the prepared pop pies in the fridge for at least 30 minutes (or up to 24 hours). Alternatively, you can freeze them for up to 2 months.

9. Preheat the oven to 200°C / 180°C fan / gas 6. Bake the pop pies for about 20 minutes, or until the pastry is golden and the filling is bubbling through the holes. If cooking from frozen, bake for an extra 5 minutes.

10. Remove the pies from the oven and allow them to cool for at least 20 minutes.

11. Meanwhile, crush the 6 reserved raspberries until juicy and mix them with the icing sugar to make a thick icing.

12. Spread the icing thinly over the cooled pop pies and sprinkle with freeze-dried raspberries or sprinkles if you like.

Serve warm or cold (they're also good for breakfast or with cream/custard as dessert).
explanation: The answer provides an easy 50-minute recipe for Peach Melba pop pies using raspberries and canned peach slices, with ingredients and step-by-step instructions, directly addressing the user's request.

question: Vegan sticky toffee pear pudding with poached Conference pears and pitted dates — where can I find this recipe?
llm_answer:
Vegan sticky toffee pear pudding (with poached Conference pears and pitted dates)

Difficulty: More effort
Total cooking time: 75 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 8 small firm pears (we used Conference)
- 200g golden caster sugar
- 2 cinnamon sticks
- 1 star anise
- 6 cloves
- Zest of 1 lemon, pared
- Zest of 1 orange, pared
- Vegan ice cream, to serve (optional)
- 250g pitted dates
- 2 tbsp linseeds
- 300ml unsweetened almond milk
- 200ml vegetable oil, plus extra for greasing
- 175g dark muscovado sugar
- 200g self-raising flour
- 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
- 1 tsp ground mixed spice
- 1/2 tsp salt

Step-by-step instructions

1. Prepare the pears
- Peel the pears and cut the bottom off each so they have a flat base and will stand upright in your tin. Trim them to a height that will fit snugly in your baking tin.
- Use a melon baller or small knife to remove the pips from the base of each pear. Roughly chop the pear scraps (discard the pips) and set the chopped scraps aside for the sponge.

2. Poach the pears
- Tip 200g golden caster sugar, the 2 cinnamon sticks, star anise, 6 cloves, the lemon and orange zests and 600ml water into a saucepan large enough to hold all the pears.
- Bring to the boil, then simmer until the sugar has dissolved.
- Add the pears, cover with a lid or a piece of baking parchment, and poach gently for about 15 minutes, until a knife easily slides into a pear.
- Remove the pears and leave them to cool in the poaching liquid.

3. Make the date mixture for the sponge
- Put 250g pitted dates and 2 tbsp linseeds in a saucepan and add 300ml unsweetened almond milk.
- Bring to a gentle simmer and cook for 2–3 minutes until the dates are soft.
- Pour the date mixture into a food processor and blitz until smooth. Add 200ml vegetable oil and blend again until combined.
- Scrape the mixture into a bowl and set aside to cool slightly.

4. Prepare oven and tin
- Heat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan) / gas 4.
- Grease and line a 20 x 30cm baking tin (a loose-bottomed one if possible) with a strip of baking parchment.

5. Make the sponge batter
- In a large mixing bowl combine 175g dark muscovado sugar, 200g self-raising flour, 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda, 1 tsp ground mixed spice and 1/2 tsp salt. Mix well, breaking up any lumps of sugar with your fingers.
- Add the cooled date-and-oil mixture to the dry ingredients and stir well to combine.
- Fold in the chopped pear scraps you set aside earlier.

6. Assemble and bake
- Scrape the cake mixture into the prepared tin and smooth the surface.
- Nestle the whole poached pears into the sponge mixture, standing them upright so the bottom halves are covered by the batter.
- Bake in the preheated oven for 35–40 minutes until the cake is cooked through. Insert a skewer into the centre of the sponge — it should come out clean. If the skewer has wet batter, bake for another 10 minutes and check again.

7. Make the toffee-ish glaze and finish
- Meanwhile, return the pear poaching liquid to the boil and simmer until reduced to a glossy syrup.
- When the pudding is cooked, allow it to cool in the tin for 5–10 minutes, then brush the entire surface (and exposed pears) with the reduced poaching syrup. Reserve a little extra syrup to serve alongside.

8. Serve
- Serve warm, brushed with extra syrup and with vegan ice cream if desired.

Enjoy your vegan sticky toffee pear pudding!
explanation: The answer provides the full recipe for vegan sticky toffee pear pudding with poached Conference pears and pitted dates, directly addressing the request for the recipe.

question: Can I make a showstopper meringue cake for entertaining using 400g strawberries, 400g cherries and 100g flaked toasted almonds?
llm_answer:
Amaretto meringue cake with strawberries & cherries
Difficulty: More effort
Total cooking time: 90 minutes
Calories (kcal): None (not provided)

Ingredients
- 400g strawberries, hulled then halved or quartered (save a few whole with stalks on, to serve)
- 400g cherries, halved and pitted (save a few whole with stalks on, to serve)
- 50g icing sugar, plus 1 tbsp
- 600ml pot double cream
- 50ml amaretto
- ½ tsp almond extract
- 6 large egg whites
- 300g white caster sugar
- ¾ tsp white wine vinegar
- 100g flaked toasted almonds

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat the oven to 140°C (120°C fan)/gas mark 1. Cut 3 pieces of baking parchment to fit 3 baking sheets for the meringues. If you don’t have 3 sheets you can cook in batches — divide the meringue mixture into 3 and cook separately.

2. Using a plate or the base of a 20cm cake tin, draw a 20cm circle on each piece of parchment, then flip the parchment so the pencil side is facing down. Put 3 oven racks in your oven — if you only have 2 but have a large grill pan, this can sit in the bottom of the oven.

3. Put the 6 egg whites in a large bowl and whisk with an electric hand whisk until thick and holding soft peaks.

4. Start adding the 300g white caster sugar, 1–2 tablespoons at a time, whisking continuously. When all the sugar has been incorporated the meringue should be thick, glossy and holding stiff peaks.

5. Add the ¾ tsp white wine vinegar and whisk briefly to combine.

6. Use a blob of meringue to stick down the corners of each piece of parchment to the trays. Divide the meringue between the 3 circles on the parchment, swirling it toward the outlines to make thin circles.

7. Scatter the 100g flaked toasted almonds over the meringues, saving a few to serve on top once assembled.

8. Bake the meringues for 1 hour, then leave to cool in the oven. When the oven is completely cold, remove the meringues and place somewhere cool and dry for up to 24 hours, or assemble straight away.

9. Meanwhile, toss the strawberries and cherries with 1 tbsp icing sugar and set aside to macerate for 10–15 minutes.

10. Pour the 600ml double cream, 50ml amaretto, ½ tsp almond extract and the remaining 50g icing sugar into a large bowl and whisk until softly whipped.

11. To assemble: use a little of the cream to stick your least successful meringue to a cake stand or plate. Spread over one third of the cream, then scatter with some of the macerated strawberries and cherries. Repeat with the second meringue layer and more cream and fruit.

12. Top with the final meringue, finish with the remaining cream and fruit, and arrange the reserved whole strawberries and cherries on top. Scatter over the remaining flaked toasted almonds.

13. Serve immediately. Leftovers will keep in the fridge for 1 day.
explanation: [The answer provides a complete recipe for an amaretto meringue cake that uses 400g strawberries, 400g cherries, and 100g flaked toasted almonds, with steps and assembly instructions—directly addressing the question about making a showstopper meringue cake for entertaining.]

question: 5-star rated vegan chocolate traybake that uses sunflower oil and a choice of soy, almond or coconut milk?
llm_answer:
Vegan chocolate party traybake
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 75 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 215ml sunflower oil, plus extra for the tin
- 300ml soy milk, almond or coconut milk
- 2 tsp apple cider vinegar
- 335g light muscovado sugar
- 1 tsp vanilla extract or vanilla bean paste
- 175g soy yogurt or coconut yogurt
- 300g self-raising flour
- 105g cocoa powder
- 1 tsp baking powder
- 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
- 100g dark dairy-free chocolate
- 140g vegan spread, at room temperature
- 1 tsp vanilla bean paste or extract
- 265g icing sugar, sifted
- ½–1 tbsp plant milk (whatever you used in the sponge)
- Colourful sprinkles (make sure they're suitable for vegans), to decorate (optional)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat the oven to 180°C/160°C fan/gas 4. Oil a 23 x 33cm baking tin (at least 4cm deep) and line the base and sides with baking parchment.

2. Whisk the 300ml plant milk and 2 tsp apple cider vinegar together in a jug – the milk should curdle slightly. Set aside.

3. In a bowl, whisk together 335g light muscovado sugar, 215ml sunflower oil and 1 tsp vanilla extract. Whisk in the 175g soy or coconut yogurt, making sure to break down any sugar lumps. Pour in the soured milk mixture and mix well.

4. Sift 300g self-raising flour, 105g cocoa powder, 1 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¼ tsp salt into a separate bowl. Stir to combine.

5. Gradually whisk the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients until you have a smooth batter. Be careful not to over-mix.

6. Pour the batter into the prepared tin and bake for 30–35 minutes, until well risen and springy and a skewer inserted into the centre comes out almost clean. A few sticky crumbs are fine, but the mixture should not be wet.

7. Leave the cake to cool in its tin for 20 minutes, then carefully turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely. Be gentle—the sponge will be delicate. The sponge will keep, covered, at room temperature for up to two days.

8. While the cake cools, make the vegan buttercream. Melt 100g dark dairy-free chocolate in the microwave or in a heatproof bowl set over a pan of simmering water. Leave to cool.

9. Beat 140g vegan spread and 1 tsp vanilla bean paste or extract on high speed in a stand mixer (or with a hand mixer) for a few minutes until pale and fluffy.

10. Add 265g sifted icing sugar gradually, starting on a low speed and then increasing to high until the mixture is light and creamy. Pour in the cooled melted chocolate and combine thoroughly. If the icing is very stiff, add ½–1 tbsp plant milk (the same milk used in the sponge) to loosen it. Chill the buttercream for at least 30 minutes before using.

11. When the cake is completely cool, spread the buttercream over the top and decorate with vegan sprinkles if desired.

12. Keep the finished traybake in the fridge to stay firm, then remove 1 hour before serving. Will keep, covered, in the fridge for up to three days.
explanation: The answer provides a vegan chocolate traybake recipe that uses sunflower oil and allows a choice of soy, almond, or coconut milk, matching the core request. It does not explicitly state a 5‑star rating, but it covers the requested ingredients and traybake format.

question: How do I make easy chickpea patties using canned chickpeas, cumin, coriander and plain flour to stuff into toasted pitta?
llm_answer:
Falafel burgers

Difficulty: Easy

Total cooking time: 16 minutes
Calories: 161 kcal

Ingredients:
- 400g can chickpeas, rinsed and drained
- 1 small red onion, roughly chopped
- 1 garlic clove, chopped
- Handful of flat-leaf or curly parsley
- 1 tsp ground cumin
- 1 tsp ground coriander
- ½ tsp harissa paste or chilli powder (optional)
- 2 tbsp plain flour
- 2 tbsp sunflower oil
- Toasted pitta bread, to serve
- 200g tub tomato salsa, to serve
- Green salad, to serve

Step-by-step instructions:
1. Drain the chickpeas and pat them dry with kitchen paper.
2. Put the chickpeas into a food processor along with the chopped red onion, chopped garlic, parsley, ground cumin, ground coriander, harissa paste (if using), plain flour and a little salt.
3. Blend until the mixture is fairly smooth and holds together.
4. Shape the mixture with your hands into four patties.
5. Heat the sunflower oil in a non-stick frying pan over medium heat.
6. Fry the patties for about 3 minutes on each side, until lightly golden.
7. Warm and split the toasted pitta breads. Stuff with the chickpea patties, spoon over tomato salsa, and serve with green salad.
explanation: The answer provides a complete recipe for making chickpea patties (falafel-style) using canned chickpeas with cumin, coriander, and plain flour, and describes stuffing them into toasted pitta, which directly matches the user's request.

question: How do I make kid-friendly chocolate squares with ground almonds and a demerara sugar topping, served with caramel sauce?
llm_answer:
Chocolate crunch with caramel sauce
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 45 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not specified

Ingredients
- 175g plain flour
- 50g ground almonds
- 60g cocoa
- 115g golden caster sugar
- 145g butter, softened, plus extra for the tin
- Demerara sugar, for sprinkling over
- 4 tbsp caramel
- 50ml single cream

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan)/gas 4.
2. Put the plain flour, ground almonds, cocoa, golden caster sugar and a large pinch of salt into a food processor and whizz briefly to combine.
3. Add the softened butter and pulse/whizz until the mixture resembles damp sand.
4. Generously butter the base and sides of a small (about 15 x 25 cm) baking tin.
5. Tip the chocolate-almond mixture into the prepared tin and press it down firmly and evenly.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 30 minutes.
7. Remove the tin from the oven, sprinkle over some demerara sugar and, while the baked slab is still soft, cut into squares using a sharp knife.
8. Meanwhile, heat the caramel and single cream together in a small pan until warmed and combined (do not boil vigorously).
9. Serve the chocolate squares warm, drizzled with the caramel sauce. Leftovers can be cooled and eaten cold — they will harden somewhat, similar to shortbread.
explanation: The answer provides a complete recipe for kid-friendly chocolate squares with ground almonds and a demerara sugar topping, served with caramel sauce, including ingredients and step-by-step instructions as requested.

question: Filo pastry spinach and feta pie with spring onions, chives and ricotta — lighter, reduced-fat/salt version?
llm_answer:
Lighter spanakopita
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 95 minutes
Calories (kcal): Not specified

Ingredients
- 500g fresh spinach
- 3 tbsp rapeseed oil
- 1 shallot, finely chopped
- 6 spring onions, ends trimmed, finely chopped
- 2 garlic cloves, finely chopped
- Generous pinch of ground nutmeg
- 200g ricotta
- 1 large egg, beaten
- 2 tbsp chopped dill, plus 1 rounded tsp
- 2 tbsp snipped chives
- 2 tsp chopped mint
- 5 sheets filo pastry (each about 46 x 25cm — about 250g total weight)
- 100g feta
- Minted yogurt dip (see tip), to serve (optional)
- Tomato, cucumber & pepper salad (see tip), to serve (optional)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat and prepare spinach: Pack the spinach into a large heatproof bowl. Pour boiling water over it and press the spinach down with a wooden spoon so leaves are submerged. Leave for 1 minute to wilt, stirring a couple of times. Tip the spinach into a large colander and run under cold water to cool quickly.

2. Drain and dry the spinach: Drain well, pressing the spinach down with the wooden spoon, then squeeze out excess water with your hands. Pat the spinach dry with kitchen paper into a compact shape, lay it on a board and roughly chop. Set aside.

3. Cook the aromatics: Heat 2 tsp of the rapeseed oil in a large non-stick frying pan. Add the shallot, spring onions and garlic and fry over a fairly high heat for 3–4 minutes, stirring often, until softened and just starting to brown.

4. Finish the spinach: Lower the heat, add the chopped spinach and stir for 1 minute only to finish drying. Season with black pepper and a good pinch of nutmeg. Remove from the heat and leave to cool.

5. Make the ricotta mixture: In a bowl, stir the ricotta into the beaten egg. Mix in 2 tbsp chopped dill, the snipped chives and the chopped mint. Season with pepper and a pinch of salt (use sparingly for a reduced-salt version).

6. Prepare the tin and filo: Lightly oil a 20cm square x 4cm deep cake tin. Mix the remaining rapeseed oil with the 1 rounded tsp chopped dill. Lay the filo sheets on a large board and keep them covered with a clean, slightly damp tea towel to prevent drying.

7. Line the tin with filo: Brush the top filo sheet with a little of the dill oil, then lower it into the tin to line the base and two sides with an overhang. Brush a bit more oil over the second sheet and lay it in the tin the other way round so it drapes over and lines the base and the other two sides. Repeat the criss-cross layering with two more oiled filo sheets so the tin is completely covered with pastry overhang all round. A few wrinkles/folds are fine.

8. Combine filling and fill the tin: Stir the ricotta mixture into the cooled spinach, then crumble in the feta and lightly stir so a few chunky pieces remain. Spoon the filling into the lined tin and level it.

9. Fold and top with filo: Bring the pastry sides up and over the filling, then brush them lightly with oil. Brush the remainder of the oil over the last filo sheet on the board. Cut that sheet in half widthways and lay one half at a time, in big folds, over the filling to cover it and create a pastry topping.

10. Bake: Place the tin on a heated baking sheet and bake at 190°C/170°C fan/gas 5 for 25–30 minutes, until the pastry is crisp and golden.

11. Rest and serve: Leave to cool for 10–15 minutes. Remove the tin and transfer the pie to a serving plate. If your tin doesn’t have a loose bottom, carefully upturn it onto a flat board, then flip it over onto the serving plate. Serve warm or cold with minted yogurt dip and a tomato, cucumber & pepper salad if you like.

Notes for a lighter, reduced-fat/salt version
- This recipe already uses rapeseed oil instead of butter and ricotta (lower-fat filling) to keep it lighter.
- Use reduced-fat ricotta and reduced-salt or lower-sodium feta if available to cut salt further; reduce or omit the added pinch of salt in the ricotta mix.
- Brush filo sparingly with the dill-oil mix to keep pastry crisp but lower in fat.
explanation: The content provides a lighter version of filo pastry spinach and feta pie (spanakopita) with spring onions, chives, and ricotta, including reduced-fat and reduced-salt suggestions, and full recipe steps.

question: Can I use frozen raspberries for a white chocolate chip muffin recipe that has a 30-minute bake time?
llm_answer:
Raspberry & white chocolate muffins

Difficulty: Easy

Ingredients
- 100g unsalted butter, softened
- 65g caster sugar
- 65g light brown sugar
- 2 large eggs, room temperature
- 125g Greek yogurt
- 1 tsp vanilla paste
- 5 tbsp milk
- 250g self-raising flour
- 1 tsp baking powder
- 200g raspberries (fresh or frozen)
- 75g white chocolate chips

Step-by-step instructions
1. Heat the oven to 200°C / 180°C fan / gas 6 and line a 12-hole muffin tin with paper cases.
2. Beat the butter and both sugars together for 5 minutes until pale and fluffy.
3. Add the eggs gradually and beat in until combined.
4. Stir in the yogurt, vanilla and milk.
5. Fold in the flour, baking powder and a pinch of fine salt until you have a smooth batter.
6. Finally, fold in 150g of the raspberries and the white chocolate chips and fill the muffin cases three-quarters full.
7. Push 2 raspberries into the top of each muffin so they're sticking out slightly.
8. Bake for 8 minutes, then reduce the oven to 180°C / 160°C fan / gas 4 and bake for a further 20–25 minutes, until risen and golden and a cocktail stick inserted into the centre comes out clean.
9. Remove from the oven and cool slightly in the tin before transferring to a wire rack.

Total cooking time: 50 minutes

Calories (kcal): Not provided
explanation: The recipe explicitly allows frozen raspberries (200g raspberries (fresh or frozen)) and the bake steps total around 28–33 minutes (8 minutes + 20–25 minutes), which aligns with a 30-minute bake time.

question: Can I make a silky white chocolate and raspberry no-bake cheesecake using melted butter and gluten-free digestives for the base?
llm_answer:
Gluten-free white chocolate & raspberry cheesecake
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time (minutes): 25
Calories (kcal): Not provided

Ingredients
- 200g white chocolate, plus extra to decorate (optional)
- 275g gluten-free digestive biscuits
- 100g unsalted butter, melted
- 500g full-fat soft cheese
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- 300ml double cream
- 300g fresh raspberries

Step-by-step instructions
1. An hour before you begin, remove all the ingredients from the fridge and bring to room temperature. Line the base of a 20cm springform cake tin with baking parchment.

2. Melt the white chocolate in a heatproof bowl in the microwave for 1 minute, stirring halfway through. If necessary, return it for further 10-second bursts until melted. Alternatively, melt the chocolate in a heatproof bowl set over a pan of just-simmering water, ensuring the bottom of the bowl doesn’t touch the water. Leave the chocolate to cool while you make the base.

3. Blitz the gluten-free digestives in a food processor, then tip into a bowl (or crush in a bag using the end of a rolling pin). Pour in the melted butter and mix until the texture resembles damp sand. Tip the mixture into the prepared tin and press down to form an even layer. Keep chilled while you make the filling.

4. Beat together the soft cheese, vanilla extract and double cream in a bowl using an electric whisk until thick and creamy. Fold through the cooled melted white chocolate — if it seizes, you can pop the bowl in the microwave for 10 seconds before whisking to bring it back together. Stir through 250g of the raspberries, allowing some to break up to create a ripple effect.

5. Spoon the cheesecake mixture over the biscuit base and smooth to an even layer. Put in the fridge to chill for at least 6 hours, or overnight.

6. To serve, carefully remove from the tin and scatter over the remaining raspberries, then grate over some extra white chocolate if you like.

Storage: Will keep chilled for two days.
explanation: The answer provides a no-bake cheesecake recipe that uses melted butter and gluten-free digestive biscuits for the base, matching the user's query about making a silky white chocolate and raspberry no-bake cheesecake.

question: How do I make a quick, easy sweet potato and rosemary soup with garlic toasts in about 30 minutes?
llm_answer:
Sweet potato & rosemary soup with garlic toasts
Difficulty: Easy
Total cooking time: 30 minutes
Calories (kcal): not provided

Ingredients
- 2 tsp olive oil, plus extra for brushing
- 1 onion, chopped
- 3 garlic cloves
- 750 g sweet potato, peeled and cubed
- 1 L vegetable stock
- 2 rosemary sprigs
- 8 slices bread (ciabatta is good)
- Salt and pepper (to taste)

Step-by-step instructions
1. Prep: Peel and cube the sweet potato, chop the onion, and separate the garlic cloves (you’ll use 2 crushed and 1 for rubbing on the bread). Strip the rosemary leaves from one sprig; keep the other sprig for rubbing on the bread.

2. Cook the aromatics: Heat 2 tsp olive oil in a large saucepan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and fry until soft (about 5–7 minutes).

3. Add garlic: Crush 2 garlic cloves and add to the softened onion. Fry for 1 minute more until fragrant.

4. Add sweet potato and stock: Stir in the cubed sweet potato, pour in the vegetable stock to cover, and bring to the boil.

5. Add rosemary and simmer: Strip the leaves from one rosemary sprig and add them to the pan. Reduce heat and simmer for about 10 minutes, or until the sweet potato is soft.

6. Make the garlic toasts and heat the oven: While the soup simmers, preheat the oven to 200°C (fan 180°C/gas mark 6). Arrange the bread slices on a baking sheet and brush lightly with olive oil.

7. Flavor the bread: Slice the remaining garlic clove in half. Rub the cut side over each oiled bread slice to impart garlic flavor. Rub the leaves from the second rosemary sprig over the bread as well. Season the slices with a little salt and pepper if you like.

8. Bake the toasts: Bake the bread slices in the preheated oven for about 10 minutes, until crisp and golden.

9. Purée the soup: When the sweet potato is tender, use a hand blender to roughly purée the soup to your desired texture. If the soup seems too thick, add a splash of the hot cooking water or extra stock to loosen it.

10. Season and serve: Taste and season the soup with salt and pepper. Pour into warmed bowls and serve immediately with the garlic toasts.

Enjoy your quick sweet potato & rosemary soup with garlicky toasts!
explanation: The answer provides a complete, step-by-step recipe for a quick sweet potato and rosemary soup with garlic toasts, aligned with the requested 30-minute timeframe.
